In a 2021 study of environmental DNA (eDNA)—genetic material shed into the environment by organisms—in the Arctic, Yucheng Wang and colleagues found mammoth eDNA in sedimentary layers formed millennia later, around 4 kyr ago. To account for this discrepancy, Joshua H. Miller and Carl Simpson proposed that arctic temperatures could preserve a mammoth carcass on the surface, allowing it to leach DNA into the environment, for several thousand years.
questions.text2: Wang and colleagues concede that eDNA contains DNA from both living organisms and carcasses, but for DNA to leach from remains over several millennia requires that the remains be perpetually on the surface. Scavengers and weathering in the Arctic, however, are likely to break down surface remains well before a thousand years have passed.
questions.question: Which choice best describes how Text 1 and Text 2 relate to each other?

options.A: Text 1 discusses two approaches to studying mammoth extinction without advocating for either, whereas Text 2 advocates for one approach over the other.
options.B: Text 1 presents findings by Wang and colleagues and gives another research team’s attempt to explain those findings, whereas Text 2 provides additional detail that calls that explanation into question.
options.C: Text 1 describes Wang and colleagues’ study and a critique of their methodology, whereas Text 2 offers additional details showing that methodology to be sound.
options.D: Text 1 argues that new research has undermined the standard view of when mammoths went extinct, whereas Text 2 suggests a way to reconcile the standard view with that new research.

questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer. Text 1 introduces the findings of Wang and colleagues and then presents the Miller and Simpson hypothesis as an explanation for why mammoth eDNA appears in sedimentary layers much later than the fossil record indicates. Text 2, however, challenges this hypothesis by providing additional details—namely, that in the Arctic, scavengers and weathering would likely break down surface remains long before they could leach DNA for thousands of years. This directly calls into question the viability of the Miller and Simpson explanation mentioned in Text 1.

questions.text1: Although food writing is one of the most widely read genres in the United States, literary scholars have long neglected it. And within this genre, cookbooks attract the least scholarly attention of all, regardless of how well written they may be. This is especially true of works dedicated to regional US cuisines, whose complexity and historical significance are often overlooked.
questions.text2: With her 1976 cookbook The Taste of Country Cooking, Edna Lewis popularized the refined Southern cooking she had grown up with in Freetown, an all-Black community in Virginia. She also set a new standard for cookbook writing: the recipes and memoir passages interspersing them are written in prose more elegant than that of most novels. Yet despite its inarguable value as a piece of writing, Lewis’s masterpiece has received almost no attention from literary scholars.
questions.question: Based on the two texts, how would the author of Text 1 most likely regard the situation presented in the underlined sentence in Text 2?

options.A: As typical, because scholars are dismissive of literary works that achieve popularity with the general public
options.B: As unsurprising, because scholars tend to overlook the literary value of food writing in general and of regional cookbooks in particular
options.C: As justifiable, because Lewis incorporated memoir into The Taste of Country Cooking, thus undermining its status as a cookbook
options.D: As inevitable, because The Taste of Country Cooking was marketed to readers of food writing and not to readers of other genres

questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer. Text 1 explains that literary scholars largely neglect food writing and especially regional cookbooks, regardless of their quality, due to an oversight of their complexity and historical significance. Thus, the fact that Edna Lewis’s well-regarded cookbook has received little scholarly attention, as mentioned in Text 2, would be seen as unsurprising by the author of Text 1. Choices A, C, and D introduce reasons that are not supported by the texts.

questions.text1: Some animal species, like the leopard, can be found in many kinds of areas. On the other hand, tropical mountain bird species tend to be limited in the types of spaces they can call home. This is because many mountain bird species are only able to survive at very specific elevations. Over time, these species have likely become used to living at a specific temperature. Therefore, these species struggle to survive at elevations that are warmer or colder than they are used to.
questions.text2: A new study reviewed observations of nearly 3,000 bird species to understand why tropical mountain bird species live at specific elevations. They noted that when a mountain bird species was found in an area with many other bird species, it tended to inhabit much smaller geographic areas. It is thus likely that competition for resources with other species, not temperature, limits where these birds can live.
questions.question: Based on the texts, both authors would most likely agree with which statement?

options.A: Tropical mountain bird species are restricted in where they can live.
options.B: Scientists have better tools to observe tropical mountain birds than they did in the past.
options.C: Little is known about how tropical mountain birds build their nests.
options.D: Tropical mountain bird species that live at high elevations tend to be genetically similar.

questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer because both texts agree that tropical mountain bird species have limited habitats. Text 1 attributes this limitation to temperature preferences, while Text 2 argues that competition for resources restricts their geographic range. Despite their differing explanations, both texts concur that these birds are confined to specific areas. The other choices introduce ideas that are not supported by either text.

questions.text1: American sculptor Edmonia Lewis is best known for her sculptures that represent figures from history and mythology, such as The Death of Cleopatra and Hagar. Although Lewis sculpted other subjects, her career as a sculptor is best represented by the works in which she depicted these historical and mythical themes.
questions.text2: Art historians have typically ignored the many portrait busts Edmonia Lewis created. Lewis likely carved these busts (sculptures of a person’s head) frequently throughout her long career. She is known for her sculptures that represent historical figures, but Lewis likely supported herself financially by carving portrait busts for acquaintances who paid her to represent their features. Thus, Lewis’s portrait busts are a central aspect of her career as a sculptor.
questions.question: Based on the texts, both authors would most likely agree with which statement?

options.A: Lewis’s portrait busts have overshadowed her other work.
options.B: The Death of Cleopatra is Lewis’s most famous piece.
options.C: Sculpting representations of historical figures was a short-lived trend.
options.D: Lewis’s works are varied in the subjects they depict.

questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer. Text 1 notes that although Lewis is best known for her sculptures of historical and mythical figures, she also sculpted other subjects, indicating variation in her work. Text 2 emphasizes that Lewis carved many portrait busts throughout her career, which further implies that her oeuvre is diverse. Choices A, B, and C are not supported by the texts.

questions.text1: Ecologists have long wondered how thousands of microscopic phytoplankton species can live together near ocean surfaces competing for the same resources. According to conventional wisdom, one species should emerge after outcompeting the rest. So why do so many species remain? Ecologists’ many efforts to explain this phenomenon still haven’t uncovered a satisfactory explanation.
questions.text2: Ecologist Michael Behrenfeld and colleagues have connected phytoplankton’s diversity to their microscopic size. Because these organisms are so tiny, they are spaced relatively far apart from each other in ocean water and, moreover, experience that water as a relatively dense substance. This in turn makes it hard for them to move around and interact with one another. Therefore, says Behrenfeld’s team, direct competition among phytoplankton probably happens much less than previously thought.
questions.question: Based on the texts, how would Behrenfeld and colleagues (Text 2) most likely respond to the 'conventional wisdom' discussed in Text 1?

options.A: By arguing that it is based on a misconception about phytoplankton species competing with one another
options.B: By asserting that it fails to recognize that routine replenishment of ocean nutrients prevents competition between phytoplankton species
options.C: By suggesting that their own findings help clarify how phytoplankton species are able to compete with larger organisms
options.D: By recommending that more ecologists focus their research on how competition among phytoplankton species is increased with water density

questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer because, based on Text 2, Behrenfeld and colleagues attribute the persistence of many phytoplankton species to a reduced level of direct competition due to the organisms’ microscopic size and the way they are spaced apart in water. This directly challenges the conventional view from Text 1 that intense competition should allow only one species to dominate. The other choices either introduce factors not mentioned in the texts or misinterpret the findings.

questions.text1: A team led by Bernardo Strassburg has found that rewilding farmland (returning the land to its natural state) could help preserve biodiversity and offset carbon emissions. The amount of farmland that would need to be restored, they found, is remarkably low. Rewilding a mere 15% of the world’s current farmland would prevent 60% of expected species extinctions and help absorb nearly 299 gigatons of carbon dioxide—a clear win in the fight against the biodiversity and climate crises.
questions.text2: While Strassburg’s team’s findings certainly offer encouraging insight into the potential benefits of rewilding, it’s important to consider potential effects on global food supplies. The researchers suggest that to compensate for the loss of food-producing land, remaining farmland would need to produce even more food. Thus, policies focused on rewilding farmland must also address strategies for higher-yield farming.
questions.question: Which choice best describes a difference in how the author of Text 1 and the author of Text 2 view Strassburg’s team’s study?

options.A: The author of Text 2 approaches the study’s findings with some caution, whereas the author of Text 1 is optimistic about the reported potential environmental benefits.
options.B: The author of Text 2 claims that the percentage of farmland identified by Strassburg’s team is too low for rewilding to achieve meaningful results, whereas the author of Text 1 thinks the percentage is sufficient.
options.C: The author of Text 2 believes that the results described by Strassburg’s team are achievable in the near future, whereas the author of Text 1 argues that they likely aren’t.
options.D: The author of Text 2 focuses on rewilding’s effect on carbon emissions, whereas the author of Text 1 focuses on its effect on biodiversity.

questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer. Text 1 is highly optimistic about Strassburg’s findings, describing the potential outcomes as a 'clear win' for both biodiversity preservation and carbon dioxide absorption. In contrast, Text 2, while acknowledging the potential benefits, emphasizes the need to address the implications of rewilding on global food supplies, thus approaching the study’s findings with caution. Choices B, C, and D misrepresent the views expressed in the texts.

questions.text1: Dominique Potvin and colleagues captured five Australian magpies (Gymnorhina tibicen) to test a new design for attaching tracking devices to birds. As the researchers fitted each magpie with a tracker attached by a small harness, they noticed some magpies without trackers pecking at another magpie’s tracker until it broke off. The researchers suggest that this behavior could be evidence of magpies attempting to help another magpie without benefiting themselves.
questions.text2: It can be tempting to think that animals are deliberately providing help when we see them removing trackers and other equipment from one another, especially when a species is known to exhibit other cooperative behaviors. At the same time, it can be difficult to exclude the possibility that individuals are simply interested in the equipment because of its novelty, curiously pawing or pecking at it until it detaches.
questions.question: Based on the texts, how would the author of Text 2 most likely respond to the researchers’ perspective in Text 1 on the behavior of the magpies without trackers?

options.A: That behavior might have been due to the novelty of the magpies’ captive setting rather than to the novelty of the tracker.
options.B: That behavior likely indicates that the magpies were deliberately attempting to benefit themselves by obtaining the tracker.
options.C: That behavior may not be evidence of selflessness in Gymnorhina tibicen because not all the captured magpies demonstrated it.
options.D: That behavior might be adequately explained without suggesting that the magpies were attempting to assist the other magpie.

questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer because it reflects the perspective in Text 2 that cautions against immediately assuming a prosocial motive for the behavior observed by Potvin and colleagues in Text 1. Instead of interpreting the pecking as an attempt to help another bird, the author of Text 2 suggests that the behavior could be simply attributed to curiosity about the novel tracking device. Choices A, B, and C do not accurately capture the alternative explanation provided in Text 2.

questions.text1: Polar bears sustain themselves primarily by hunting seals on the Arctic sea ice, but rising ocean temperatures are causing the ice to diminish, raising concerns about polar bear population declines as these large predators’ seal-hunting habitats continue to shrink. A 2020 study examining polar bear populations across the Arctic concluded that populations affected by sea-ice loss are at great risk of extinction by the end of the twenty-first century.
questions.text2: Monitoring carried out by researchers from the Norwegian Polar Institute shows that the polar bear population on the Arctic archipelago of Svalbard remains stable and well nourished despite rapidly declining sea ice in recent years. The researchers attribute this population’s resilience in part to a shift in feeding strategies: in addition to hunting seals, the Svalbard polar bears have begun relying on a diet of reindeer meat and birds’ eggs.
questions.question: Based on the texts, how would the researchers in Text 2 most likely respond to the conclusion presented in the underlined portion of Text 1?

options.A: By noting that it neglects the possibility of some polar bear populations adapting to changes in their environment
options.B: By suggesting that it is likely incorrect about the rates at which warming ocean temperatures have caused sea ice to melt in the Arctic
options.C: By asserting that it overlooks polar bear populations that have not yet been affected by loss of seal-hunting habitats
options.D: By arguing that it fails to account for polar bears’ reliance on a single seal-hunting strategy

questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer. Text 2 shows that the Svalbard polar bears have adapted their feeding strategies by supplementing their diet with reindeer meat and birds’ eggs in response to declining sea ice. This adaptation demonstrates that at least some polar bear populations may be resilient in the face of environmental changes, which challenges the claim in Text 1 that such populations are at great risk of extinction if reliant solely on seal hunting. Choices B, C, and D introduce ideas not supported by the texts.

questions.text: “How lifelike are they?” Many computer animators prioritize this question as they strive to create ever more realistic environments and lighting. Generally, while characters in computer-animated films appear highly exaggerated, environments and lighting are carefully engineered to mimic reality. But some animators, such as Pixar’s Sanjay Patel, are focused on a different question. Rather than asking first whether the environments and lighting they’re creating are convincingly lifelike, Patel and others are asking whether these elements reflect their films’ unique stories.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the function of the underlined question in the text as a whole?

options.A: It reflects a primary goal that many computer animators have for certain components of the animations they produce.
options.B: It represents a concern of computer animators who are more interested in creating unique backgrounds and lighting effects than realistic ones.
options.C: It conveys the uncertainty among many computer animators about how to create realistic animations using current technology.
options.D: It illustrates a reaction that audiences typically have to the appearance of characters created by computer animators.

questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer because it most accurately describes the function of the underlined question in the text as a whole. The text begins with the underlined question, 'How lifelike are they?' and goes on to explain that many computer animators pose this question as they strive to make their environments and lighting convincingly realistic. Later, the text contrasts this goal with the approach of animators like Sanjay Patel, who instead focus on whether these elements reflect their films’ unique stories. Thus, the underlined question reflects a primary goal of achieving realistic components in animation.

questions.text: The field of study called affective neuroscience seeks instinctive, physiological causes for feelings such as pleasure or displeasure. Because these sensations are linked to a chemical component (for example, the release of the neurotransmitter dopamine in the brain when one receives or expects a reward), they can be said to have a partly physiological basis. These processes have been described in mammals, but Jingnan Huang and his colleagues have recently observed that some behaviors of honeybees (such as foraging) are also motivated by a dopamine-based signaling process.
questions.question: What choice best describes the main purpose of the text?

options.A: It describes an experimental method of measuring the strength of physiological responses in humans.
options.B: It illustrates processes by which certain insects can express how they are feeling.
options.C: It summarizes a finding suggesting that some mechanisms in the brains of certain insects resemble mechanisms in mammalian brains.
options.D: It presents research showing that certain insects and mammals behave similarly when there is a possibility of a reward for their actions.

questions.rationale: Choice C is the best answer because it most accurately describes the main purpose of the text. The text explains that affective neuroscience links feelings to physiological processes (e.g., dopamine release) in mammals and then notes that similar dopamine-based signaling has recently been observed in honeybees during behaviors like foraging. This summary highlights the finding that some brain mechanisms in insects resemble those in mammals, thus reinforcing the purpose of the text.

questions.text:
The following text is from Srimati Svarna Kumari Devi’s 1894 novel The Fatal Garland (translated by A. Christina Albers in 1910). Shakti is walking near a riverbank that she visited frequently during her childhood. 

"She crossed the woods she knew so well. The trees seemed to extend their branches like welcoming arms. They greeted her as an old friend. Soon she reached the river-side."
questions.question: Which choice best describes the function of the underlined portion in the text as a whole?

options.A: It suggests that Shakti feels uncomfortable near the river.
options.B: It indicates that Shakti has lost her sense of direction in the woods.
options.C: It emphasizes Shakti’s sense of belonging in the landscape.
options.D: It conveys Shakti’s appreciation for her long-term friendships.

questions.rationale: Choice C is the best answer because it most accurately describes how the underlined portion functions in the text as a whole. The description of the trees extending their branches like welcoming arms and greeting her as an old friend emphasizes Shakti's familiarity with and comfort in the wooded landscape, underscoring her sense of belonging there.

questions.text: Early in the Great Migration of 1910–1970, which involved the mass migration of Black people from the southern to the northern United States, political activist and Chicago Defender writer Fannie Barrier Williams was instrumental in helping other Black women establish themselves in the North. Many women hoped for better employment opportunities in the North because, in the South, they faced much competition for domestic employment and men tended to get agricultural work. To aid with this transition, Barrier Williams helped secure job placement in the North for many women before they even began their journey.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main purpose of the text?

options.A: To introduce and illustrate Barrier Williams’s integral role in supporting other Black women as their circumstances changed during part of the Great Migration
options.B: To establish that Barrier Williams used her professional connections to arrange employment for other Black women, including jobs with the Chicago Defender
options.C: To demonstrate that the factors that motivated the start of the Great Migration were different for Black women than they were for Black men
options.D: To provide an overview of the employment challenges faced by Black women in the agricultural and domestic spheres in the southern United States

questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer because it most accurately describes the text’s purpose, which is to discuss the important role Fannie Barrier Williams played in supporting Black women during the early years of the Great Migration by securing job placements for them as they relocated to the North.

questions.text: Studying late nineteenth- and early twentieth-century artifacts from an agricultural and domestic site in Texas, archaeologist Ayana O. Flewellen found that Black women employed as farm workers utilized hook-and-eye closures to fasten their clothes at the waist, giving themselves a silhouette similar to the one that was popular in contemporary fashion and typically achieved through more restrictive garments such as corsets. Flewellen argues that this sartorial practice shows that these women balanced hegemonic ideals of femininity with the requirements of their physically demanding occupation.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main purpose of the text?

options.A: To describe an unexpected discovery that altered a researcher’s view of how rapidly fashions among Black female farmworkers in late nineteenth- and early twentieth-century Texas changed during the period
options.B: To discuss research that investigated the ways in which Black female farmworkers in late nineteenth- and early twentieth-century Texas used fashion practices to resist traditional gender ideals
options.C: To evaluate a scholarly work that offers explanations for the impact of urban fashion ideals on Black female farmworkers in late nineteenth- and early twentieth-century Texas
options.D: To summarize the findings of a study that explored factors influencing a fashion practice among Black female farmworkers in late nineteenth- and early twentieth-century Texas

questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer because the text provides an overview of research findings that examine how Black female farmworkers in Texas used hook-and-eye closures in their clothing to achieve a fashionable silhouette despite the physical demands of their occupation.

questions.text: Astronomers are confident that the star Betelgeuse will eventually consume all the helium in its core and explode in a supernova. They are much less confident, however, about when this will happen, since that depends on internal characteristics of Betelgeuse that are largely unknown. Astrophysicist Sarafina El-Badry Nance and colleagues recently investigated whether acoustic waves in the star could be used to determine internal stellar states but concluded that this method could not sufficiently reveal Betelgeuse’s internal characteristics to allow its evolutionary state to be firmly fixed.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the function of the second sentence in the overall structure of the text?

options.A: It describes a serious limitation of the method used by Nance and colleagues.
options.B: It presents the central finding reported by Nance and colleagues.
options.C: It identifies the problem that Nance and colleagues attempted to solve but did not.
options.D: It explains how the work of Nance and colleagues was received by others in the field.

questions.rationale: Choice C is the best answer because the second sentence introduces the uncertainty regarding when Betelgeuse will explode, which is due to the unknown internal characteristics of the star. This identifies the problem that Nance and colleagues attempted to address but ultimately could not resolve with their method.

questions.text: Archeological excavation of Market Street Chinatown, a nineteenth-century Chinese American community in San Jose, California, provided the first evidence that Asian food products were imported to the United States in the 1800s: bones from a freshwater fish species native to Southeast Asia. Jinshanzhuang—Hong Kong–based import/export firms—likely coordinated the fish’s transport from Chinese-operated fisheries in Vietnam and Malaysia to North American markets. This route reveals the (often overlooked) multinational dimensions of the trade networks linking Chinese diaspora communities.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the function of the underlined sentence in the text as a whole?

options.A: It explains why efforts to determine the country of origin of the items mentioned in the previous sentence remain inconclusive.
options.B: It provides information that helps support a claim about a discovery’s significance that is presented in the following sentence.
options.C: It traces the steps that were taken to locate and recover the objects that are described in the previous sentence.
options.D: It outlines a hypothesis that additional evidence discussed in the following sentence casts some doubt on.

questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer. The underlined sentence provides details about how Hong Kong–based import/export firms coordinated the transport of the fish, thereby supporting the claim made in the following sentence about the multinational dimensions of trade networks within Chinese diaspora communities.

questions.text: Using NASA’s powerful James Webb Space Telescope (JWST), Mercedes López-Morales and colleagues measured the wavelengths of light traveling through the atmosphere of WASP-39b, an exoplanet, or planet outside our solar system. Different molecules absorb different wavelengths of light, and the wavelength measurements showed the presence of carbon dioxide (CO₂) in WASP-39b’s atmosphere. This finding not only offers the first decisive evidence of CO₂ in the atmosphere of an exoplanet but also illustrates the potential for future scientific breakthroughs held by the JWST.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the overall structure of the text?

options.A: It discusses a method used by some researchers, then states why an alternative method is superior to it.
options.B: It describes how researchers made a scientific discovery, then explains the importance of that discovery.
options.C: It outlines the steps taken in a scientific study, then presents a hypothesis based on that study.
options.D: It examines how a group of scientists reached a conclusion, then shows how other scientists have challenged that conclusion.

questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer. The text first describes how researchers used the JWST to detect CO₂ in WASP-39b’s atmosphere and then explains the significance of this discovery, including its importance as the first decisive evidence of CO₂ and its implications for future breakthroughs.

questions.text: Researchers have found a nearly 164,000-year-old molar from a member of the archaic human species known as Denisovans in a cave in Laos, suggesting that Denisovans lived in a wider range of environments than indicated by earlier evidence. Before the discovery, Denisovans were thought to have lived only at high altitudes in relatively cold climates in what are now Russia and China, but the discovery of the tooth in Laos suggests that they may have lived at low altitudes in relatively warm climates in Southeast Asia as well.
questions.question: Which choice best states the function of the underlined portion in the text as a whole?

options.A: It dismisses as untrue the research presented in the previous sentence.
options.B: It defines a term used in the description that follows in the rest of the sentence.
options.C: It emphasizes the main goal of the research introduced in the previous sentence.
options.D: It provides context that clarifies the significance of the information that follows in the rest of the sentence.

questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer. The underlined portion explains what was previously believed about Denisovan habitats, thereby providing context that highlights the significance of the new discovery (i.e., that Denisovans may have also occupied low-altitude, warm environments).

questions.text: According to historian Vicki L. Ruiz, Mexican American women made crucial contributions to the labor movement during World War II. At the time, food processing companies entered into contracts to supply United States armed forces with canned goods. Increased production quotas conferred greater bargaining power on the companies’ employees, many of whom were Mexican American women: employees insisted on more favorable benefits, and employers, who were anxious to fulfill the contracts, complied. Thus, labor activism became a platform for Mexican American women to assert their agency.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the function of the underlined portion in the text as a whole?

options.A: It elaborates on a claim about labor relations in a particular industry made earlier in the text.
options.B: It offers an example of a trend in the World War II–era economy discussed earlier in the text.
options.C: It notes a possible exception to the historical narrative of labor activism sketched earlier in the text.
options.D: It provides further details about the identities of the workers discussed earlier in the text.

questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer because the underlined portion provides an example illustrating how increased production quotas led to greater bargaining power for Mexican American women, thereby elaborating on the text’s claim about improved labor relations in the food processing industry during World War II.

questions.text:
The following text is from Charlotte Brontë’s 1847 novel Jane Eyre. Jane, the narrator, works as a governess at Thornfield Hall.
I went on with my day’s business tranquilly; but ever and anon vague suggestions kept wandering across my brain of reasons why I should quit Thornfield; and I kept involuntarily framing advertisements and pondering conjectures about new situations: these thoughts I did not think to check; they might germinate and bear fruit if they could.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main purpose of the text?

options.A: To convey a contrast between Jane’s outward calmness and internal restlessness
options.B: To emphasize Jane’s loyalty to the people she works for at Thornfield Hall
options.C: To demonstrate that Jane finds her situation both challenging and deeply fulfilling
options.D: To describe Jane’s determination to secure employment outside of Thornfield Hall

questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer because the text shows that despite Jane’s calm demeanor, she is internally restless and preoccupied with thoughts about leaving her job at Thornfield. This contrast between outward calm and internal agitation is central to the passage.

questions.text: Yawn contagion occurs when one individual yawns in response to another’s yawn. Studies of this behavior in primates have focused on populations in captivity, but biologist Elisabetta Palagi and her colleagues have shown that it can occur in wild primate populations as well. In their study, which focused on a wild population of gelada monkeys (Theropithecus gelada) in Ethiopia, the researchers further reported that yawn contagion most commonly occurred in males and across different social groups instead of within a single social group.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the function of the first sentence in the text as a whole?

options.A: It defines a phenomenon that is discussed in the text.
options.B: It introduces a problem that is examined in the text.
options.C: It makes a claim that is challenged in the text.
options.D: It presents a hypothesis that is evaluated in the text.

questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer because the first sentence provides a clear definition of yawn contagion—the phenomenon of one individual yawning in response to another’s yawn—which sets the stage for the rest of the text that discusses research findings about this behavior in wild primate populations.

questions.text:
The following text is adapted from Herman Melville’s 1857 novel The Confidence-Man. Humphry Davy was a prominent British chemist and inventor.
Years ago, a grave American savant, being in London, observed at an evening party there, a certain coxcombical fellow, as he thought, an absurd ribbon in his lapel, and full of smart [banter], whisking about to the admiration of as many as were disposed to admire. Great was the savant’s disdain; but, chancing ere long to find himself in a corner with the jackanapes, got into conversation with him, when he was somewhat ill-prepared for the good sense of the jackanapes, but was altogether thrown aback, upon subsequently being [informed that he was] no less a personage than Sir Humphry Davy.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main purpose of the text?

options.A: It portrays the thoughts of a character who is embarrassed about his own behavior.
options.B: It presents an account of a misunderstanding.
options.C: It offers a short history of how a person came to be famous.
options.D: It explains why one character dislikes another.

questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer. The text tells a story of a first impression that turned out to be wrong: a serious American savant dismissed a seemingly foolish guest at a British party, only to later be shocked when he learned that the guest was actually Sir Humphry Davy, a prominent chemist and inventor.

questions.text: Historians Tiya Miles and Roy E. Finkenbine have both documented the assistance Indigenous peoples gave to Black freedom seekers leaving the South before the US Civil War. Much of the historical evidence of this help comes from Indigenous oral traditions and from autobiographies written by the freedom seekers. One such narrative is Jermain Loguen’s autobiography, which tells about how Neshnabé (Potawatomi) villagers offered him food, lodging, and directions during his 1835 journey from Tennessee to Canada.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the function of the underlined sentence?

options.A: It provides an example of an autobiography that describes help given by an Indigenous people to a Black freedom seeker.
options.B: It shows why Loguen decided to write in great detail about his experiences traveling from Tennessee to Canada in his autobiography.
options.C: It argues that autobiographies are particularly important sources of information about geography in the United States before the Civil War.
options.D: It suggests that most historians believe that Neshnabé villagers were more successful in assisting freedom seekers than other people were.

questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer. The sentence specifically identifies Jermain Loguen’s autobiography as a narrative that describes how Neshnabé (Potawatomi) villagers provided essential assistance to him during his journey. This serves as a concrete example of the type of evidence—autobiographical accounts—that historians such as Miles and Finkenbine use to document the help given by Indigenous peoples to Black freedom seekers.

questions.text:
The following text is from Joseph Conrad’s 1907 novel The Secret Agent: A Simple Tale. Mr. Verloc is navigating the London streets on his way to a meeting.
Before reaching Knightsbridge, Mr. Verloc took a turn to the left out of the busy main thoroughfare, uproarious with the traffic of swaying omnibuses and trotting vans, in the almost silent, swift flow of hansoms [horse-drawn carriages]. Under his hat, worn with a slight backward tilt, his hair had been carefully brushed into respectful sleekness; for his business was with an Embassy. And Mr. Verloc, steady like a rock—a soft kind of rock—marched now along a street which could with every propriety be described as private.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the function of the underlined phrase in the text as a whole?

options.A: It qualifies an earlier description of Mr. Verloc.
options.B: It emphasizes an internal struggle Mr. Verloc experiences.
options.C: It contrasts Mr. Verloc with his surroundings.
options.D: It reveals a private opinion Mr. Verloc holds.

questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer. The underlined phrase 'steady like a rock—a soft kind of rock' qualifies the earlier description of Mr. Verloc by modifying his characterization, suggesting that while he is steady, there is also a degree of softness about his demeanor. This additional detail refines our understanding of his character rather than indicating an internal struggle, a contrast with his surroundings, or revealing a private opinion.

questions.text: In 1973, poet Miguel Algarín started inviting other writers who, like him, were Nuyorican—a term for New Yorkers of Puerto Rican heritage—to gather in his apartment to present their work. The gatherings were so well attended that Algarín soon had to rent space in a cafe to accommodate them. Thus, the Nuyorican Poets Cafe was born. Moving to a permanent location in 1981, the Nuyorican Poets Cafe expanded its original scope beyond the written word, hosting art exhibitions and musical performances as well. Half a century since its inception, it continues to foster emerging Nuyorican talent.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the overall purpose of the text?

options.A: To explain what motivated Algarín to found the Nuyorican Poets Cafe
options.B: To situate the Nuyorican Poets Cafe within the cultural life of New York as a whole
options.C: To discuss why the Nuyorican Poets Cafe expanded its scope to include art and music
options.D: To provide an overview of the founding and mission of the Nuyorican Poets Cafe

questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer. The text provides a brief history of the Nuyorican Poets Cafe from its beginnings in Algarín’s apartment, through its expansion to a permanent venue that also hosts art exhibitions and musical performances, up to its ongoing role in fostering Nuyorican talent. This overview of its founding, evolution, and mission is the primary focus of the text.

questions.text: Some studies have suggested that posture can influence cognition, but we should not overstate this phenomenon. A case in point: In a 2014 study, Megan O’Brien and Alaa Ahmed had subjects stand or sit while making risky simulated economic decisions. Standing is more physically unstable and cognitively demanding than sitting; accordingly, O’Brien and Ahmed hypothesized that standing subjects would display more risk aversion during the decision-making tasks than sitting subjects did, since they would want to avoid further feelings of discomfort and complicated risk evaluations. But O’Brien and Ahmed actually found no difference in the groups’ performance.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main purpose of the text?

options.A: It argues that research findings about the effects of posture on cognition are often misunderstood, as in the case of O’Brien and Ahmed’s study.
options.B: It presents the study by O’Brien and Ahmed to critique the methods and results reported in previous studies of the effects of posture on cognition.
options.C: It explains a significant problem in the emerging understanding of posture’s effects on cognition and how O’Brien and Ahmed tried to solve that problem.
options.D: It discusses the study by O’Brien and Ahmed to illustrate why caution is needed when making claims about the effects of posture on cognition.

questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer because it shows that despite some studies suggesting posture influences cognition, O’Brien and Ahmed’s study found no difference in performance between standing and sitting subjects. This outcome exemplifies why caution is needed in making broad claims about the effects of posture on cognition.

questions.text:
The following text is from the 1923 poem “Black Finger” by Angelina Weld Grimké, a Black American writer. A cypress is a type of evergreen tree.

I have just seen a most beautiful thing,
Slim and still,
 Against a gold, gold sky,
 A straight black cypress,
Sensitive,
Exquisite,
A black finger
Pointing upwards.
Why, beautiful still finger, are you black?
And why are you pointing upwards?
questions.question: Which choice best describes the overall structure of the text?

options.A: The speaker assesses a natural phenomenon, then questions the accuracy of her assessment.
options.B: The speaker describes a distinctive sight in nature, then ponders what meaning to attribute to that sight.
options.C: The speaker presents an outdoor scene, then considers a human behavior occurring within that scene.
options.D: The speaker examines her surroundings, then speculates about their influence on her emotional state.

questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer because the poem first offers a vivid description of a beautiful natural sight—a black cypress against a golden sky—and then the speaker questions its significance, asking why the 'finger' is black and why it points upward. This structure moves from descriptive imagery to reflective pondering about its meaning.

questions.text: In Jane Austen’s novel Mansfield Park, an almost imperceptible smile from potential suitor Henry Crawford causes the protagonist Fanny Price to blush; her embarrassment grows when she suspects that he is aware of it. This moment—in which Fanny not only infers Henry’s mental state through his gestures, but also infers that he is drawing inferences about her mental state—illustrates what literary scholar George Butte calls “deep intersubjectivity,” a technique for representing interactions between consciousnesses through which Austen’s novels derive much of their social and psychological drama.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the function of the underlined sentence in the text as a whole?

options.A: It states a claim about Austen’s skill at representing psychological complexity that is reinforced by an example presented in the following sentence.
options.B: It advances an interpretation of an Austen protagonist who is contrasted with protagonists from other Austen novels cited in the following sentence.
options.C: It describes a recurring theme in Austen’s novels that is the focus of a literary scholar’s analysis summarized in the following sentence.
options.D: It provides a synopsis of an interaction in an Austen novel that illustrates a literary concept discussed in the following sentence.

questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer because the underlined sentence offers a concise account of an interaction in Mansfield Park that exemplifies 'deep intersubjectivity.' This synopsis sets up the explanation that follows about how Austen's novels employ this literary technique to develop social and psychological drama.

questions.text: In 2007, computer scientist Luis von Ahn was working on converting printed books into a digital format. He found that some words were distorted enough that digital scanners couldn’t recognize them, but most humans could easily read them. Based on that finding, von Ahn invented a simple security test to keep automated “bots” out of websites. The first version of the reCAPTCHA test asked users to type one known word and one of the many words scanners couldn’t recognize. Correct answers proved the users were humans and added data to the book-digitizing project.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main purpose of the text?

options.A: To discuss von Ahn’s invention of reCAPTCHA
options.B: To explain how digital scanners work
options.C: To call attention to von Ahn’s book-digitizing project
options.D: To indicate how popular reCAPTCHA is

questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer because the text begins by describing von Ahn’s work on converting printed books to digital format and the difficulties encountered, which led him to invent the reCAPTCHA test. The main focus is on discussing how reCAPTCHA was invented as a result of this discovery. Choices B, C, and D do not capture the primary focus, which is von Ahn’s invention of reCAPTCHA.

questions.text:
The following text is from Edith Wharton’s 1905 novel The House of Mirth. Lily Bart and a companion are walking through a park.

"Lily had no real intimacy with nature, but she had a passion for the appropriate and could be keenly sensitive to a scene which was the fitting background of her own sensations. The landscape outspread below her seemed an enlargement of her present mood, and she found something of herself in its calmness, its breadth, its long free reaches. On the nearer slopes the sugar-maples wavered like pyres of light; lower down was a massing of grey orchards, and here and there the lingering green of an oak-grove."
questions.question: Which choice best describes the function of the underlined sentence in the text as a whole?

options.A: It creates a detailed image of the physical setting of the scene.
options.B: It establishes that a character is experiencing an internal conflict.
options.C: It makes an assertion that the next sentence then expands on.
options.D: It illustrates an idea that is introduced in the previous sentence.

questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer because the text first introduces Lily’s sensitivity to scenes that reflect her mood. The underlined sentence then illustrates this idea by showing how Lily perceives the landscape as an expansion of her current mood, thereby clarifying the connection between the external setting and her internal state.

questions.text: Composer Florence Price won first place for her score Symphony in E Minor at the 1932 Wanamaker Foundation Awards. The piece was performed the following year by the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, a significant recognition of its quality. Price continued to compose many musical pieces throughout her career, blending traditional Black spirituals with classical European Romantic musical traditions. In recent years, Price’s concertos and symphonies have been performed and recorded by several major orchestras, further preserving her work for others to enjoy.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main purpose of the text?

options.A: To provide examples of Price’s importance as a composer
options.B: To argue that more major orchestras should perform Price’s compositions
options.C: To describe the musical styles that inspired many of Price’s symphonies
options.D: To compare Price’s scores with those of classical European composers

questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer because the text provides an overview of Florence Price’s significance as a composer by highlighting her success with the Wanamaker Foundation Awards, the performance of her work by the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, her blending of traditional Black spirituals with classical European Romantic musical traditions, and the continued performance and recording of her compositions by major orchestras. The other choices do not capture the overall purpose of showcasing her importance in music history.

questions.text: Some bird species don’t raise their own chicks. Instead, adult females lay their eggs in other nests, next to another bird species’ own eggs. Female cuckoos have been seen quickly laying eggs in the nests of other bird species when those birds are out looking for food. After the eggs hatch, the noncuckoo parents will typically raise the cuckoo chicks as if they were their own offspring, even if the cuckoos look very different from the other chicks.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the function of the underlined sentence in the text as a whole?

options.A: It introduces a physical feature of female cuckoos that is described later in the text.
options.B: It describes the appearance of the cuckoo nests mentioned earlier in the text.
options.C: It offers a detail about how female cuckoos carry out the behavior discussed in the text.
options.D: It explains how other birds react to the female cuckoo behavior discussed in the text.

questions.rationale: Choice C is the best answer because the underlined sentence specifically details the behavior of female cuckoos—namely, that they quickly lay eggs in the nests of other species when those birds are away—which directly illustrates how they implement the strategy of brood parasitism. The other choices either misidentify the focus of the sentence or address aspects of the text that are mentioned elsewhere.

questions.text: Mathematician Claude Shannon is widely regarded as a foundational figure in information theory. His most important paper, “A Mathematical Theory of Communication,” published in 1948 when he was employed at Bell Labs, utilized a concept called a “binary digit” (shortened to “bit”) to measure the amount of information in any signal and determine the fastest rate at which information could be transmitted while still being reliably decipherable. Robert Gallagher, one of Shannon’s colleagues, said that the bit was “[Shannon’s] discovery, and from it the whole communications revolution has sprung.”
questions.question: Which choice best describes the overall structure of the text?

options.A: It presents a theoretical concept, illustrates how the name of the concept has changed, and shows how the name has entered common usage.
options.B: It introduces a respected researcher, describes an aspect of his work, and suggests why the work is historically significant.
options.C: It names the company where an important mathematician worked, details the mathematician’s career at the company, and provides an example of the recognition he received there.
options.D: It mentions a paper, offers a summary of the paper’s findings, and presents a researcher’s commentary on the paper.

questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer because the text starts by introducing Claude Shannon as a foundational figure in information theory, then details one of his most influential contributions via his 1948 paper, and finally includes a quote from a colleague that underscores the historical significance of his work. This structure highlights both his role and the impact of his discovery, which aligns best with choice B.

questions.text: A study by a team including finance professor Madhu Veeraraghavan suggests that exposure to sunshine during the workday can lead to overly optimistic behavior. Using data spanning from 1994 to 2010 for a set of US companies, the team compared over 29,000 annual earnings forecasts to the actual earnings later reported by those companies. The team found that the greater the exposure to sunshine at work in the two weeks before a manager submitted an earnings forecast, the more the manager’s forecast exceeded what the company actually earned that year.
questions.question: Which choice best states the function of the underlined sentence in the overall structure of the text?

options.A: To summarize the results of the team’s analysis
options.B: To present a specific example that illustrates the study’s findings
options.C: To explain part of the methodology used in the team’s study
options.D: To call out a challenge the team faced in conducting its analysis

questions.rationale: Choice C is the best answer because the underlined sentence explains how the team used data (29,000 annual earnings forecasts compared to actual earnings) to test their hypothesis about sunshine's effect on optimism. This explanation of their methodology supports the study’s overall framework.

questions.text:
The following text is adapted from Louisa May Alcott’s 1869 novel An Old-Fashioned Girl. Polly, a teenager, is visiting her friend Fanny.

Fanny’s friends did not interest Polly much; she was rather afraid of them because they seemed so much older and wiser than herself, even those younger in years. They talked about things of which she knew nothing and when Fanny tried to explain, she didn’t find them interesting; indeed, some of them rather shocked and puzzled her.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main purpose of the text?

options.A: To portray Polly’s reaction to Fanny’s friends
options.B: To identify the topics Polly talks about with Fanny’s friends
options.C: To explain how Fanny met some of her friends
options.D: To illustrate how Fanny’s friends feel about Polly

questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer because the text focuses on describing Polly’s internal reaction—her fear, disinterest, and puzzlement—toward Fanny’s friends.

questions.text:
The following text is adapted from Zora Neale Hurston’s 1894 novel The Fatal Garland (translated by A. Christina Albers in 1910). Shakti is walking near a riverbank that she visited frequently during her childhood.

"She crossed the woods she knew so well. The trees seemed to extend their branches like welcoming arms. They greeted her as an old friend. Soon she reached the river-side. [John Redding] loved to wander down to the water’s edge, and, casting in dry twigs, watch them sail away down stream to Jacksonville, the sea, the wide world and [he] wanted to follow them."
questions.question: Which choice best describes the function of the underlined sentence in the text as a whole?

options.A: It provides an extended description of a location that John likes to visit.
options.B: It reveals that some residents of John’s town are confused by his behavior.
options.C: It illustrates the uniqueness of John’s imagination compared to the imaginations of other children.
options.D: It suggests that John longs to experience a larger life outside the Florida woods.

questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer because the underlined sentence shows that John sends twigs sailing away and imagines them journeying to far-off, expansive places, suggesting a longing to experience life beyond his immediate surroundings.

questions.text: A number of Indigenous politicians have been elected to the United States Congress since 2000 as members of the country’s two established political parties. In Canada and several Latin American countries, on the other hand, Indigenous people have formed their own political parties to advance candidates who will advocate for the interests of their communities. This movement has been particularly successful in Ecuador, where Guadalupe Llori, a member of the Indigenous party known as Pachakutik, was elected president of the National Assembly in 2021.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main purpose of the text?

options.A: To trace the history of an Indigenous political movement and speculate about its future development
options.B: To argue that Indigenous politicians in the United States should form their own political party
options.C: To highlight two approaches to achieving political representation for Indigenous people
options.D: To consider how Indigenous politicians in the United States have influenced Indigenous politicians in Canada and Latin America

questions.rationale: Choice C is the best answer because the text contrasts the approach of Indigenous politicians in the United States—joining existing parties—with the approach in Canada and Latin America—forming their own parties—to achieve political representation.

questions.text:
The following text is adapted from Paul Laurence Dunbar’s 1902 novel The Sport of the Gods. Joe and some of his family members have recently moved to New York City.

"[Joe] was wild with enthusiasm and with a desire to be a part of all that the metropolis meant. In the evening he saw the young fellows passing by dressed in their spruce clothes, and he wondered with a sort of envy where they could be going. Back home there had been no place much worth going to, except church and one or two people’s houses."
questions.question: Which choice best states the main purpose of the text?

options.A: It illustrates a character’s reaction to a new environment.
options.B: It explains why a character has traveled to a city.
options.C: It compares a character’s thoughts about an event at two different times of day.
options.D: It presents a character feeling regret over leaving home.

questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer because the text describes Joe’s enthusiastic reaction to the vibrant life of the city, contrasting it with the limited opportunities in his hometown.

questions.text:
The following text is from Joseph Conrad’s 1907 novel The Secret Agent: A Simple Tale. Mr. Verloc is navigating the London streets on his way to a meeting.

"Before reaching Knightsbridge, Mr. Verloc took a turn to the left out of the busy main thoroughfare, uproarious with the traffic of swaying omnibuses and trotting vans, in the almost silent, swift flow of hansoms [horse-drawn carriages]. Under his hat, worn with a slight backward tilt, his hair had been carefully brushed into respectful sleekness; for his business was with an Embassy. And Mr. Verloc, steady like a rock—a soft kind of rock—marched now along a street which could with every propriety be described as private."
questions.question: Which choice best describes the function of the underlined phrase in the text as a whole?

options.A: It qualifies an earlier description of Mr. Verloc.
options.B: It emphasizes an internal struggle Mr. Verloc experiences.
options.C: It contrasts Mr. Verloc with his surroundings.
options.D: It reveals a private opinion Mr. Verloc holds.

questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer because the underlined phrase 'steady like a rock—a soft kind of rock' adds nuance to the earlier description of Mr. Verloc, qualifying his steadfastness by implying that his solidity is tempered with a certain gentleness.

questions.text: In 1973, poet Miguel Algarín started inviting other writers who, like him, were Nuyorican—a term for New Yorkers of Puerto Rican heritage—to gather in his apartment to present their work. The gatherings were so well attended that Algarín soon had to rent space in a cafe to accommodate them. Thus, the Nuyorican Poets Cafe was born. Moving to a permanent location in 1981, the Nuyorican Poets Cafe expanded its original scope beyond the written word, hosting art exhibitions and musical performances as well. Half a century since its inception, it continues to foster emerging Nuyorican talent.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the overall purpose of the text?

options.A: To explain what motivated Algarín to found the Nuyorican Poets Cafe
options.B: To situate the Nuyorican Poets Cafe within the cultural life of New York as a whole
options.C: To discuss why the Nuyorican Poets Cafe expanded its scope to include art and music
options.D: To provide an overview of the founding and mission of the Nuyorican Poets Cafe

questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer because the text outlines the history of the Nuyorican Poets Cafe—from its humble beginnings in an apartment to its expansion into a permanent venue that fosters artistic talent—thereby offering an overview of its founding and mission.

questions.text:
The following text is from Charlotte Perkins Gilman’s 1910 poem “The Earth’s Entail.”

"No matter how we cultivate the land,
Taming the forest and the prairie free;
No matter how we irrigate the sand,
Making the desert blossom at command,
 We must always leave the borders of the sea;
 The immeasureable reaches
 Of the windy wave-wet beaches,
The million-mile-long margin of the sea."
questions.question: Which choice best describes the overall structure of the text?

options.A: The speaker argues against interfering with nature and then gives evidence supporting this interference.
options.B: The speaker presents an account of efforts to dominate nature and then cautions that such efforts are only temporary.
options.C: The speaker provides examples of an admirable way of approaching nature and then challenges that approach.
options.D: The speaker describes attempts to control nature and then offers a reminder that not all nature is controllable.

questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer because the poem contrasts human attempts to cultivate and control nature (taming, irrigating, making deserts blossom) with the uncontrollable vastness of the sea, reminding us that some aspects of nature remain beyond human control.

questions.text:
The following text is adapted from Oscar Wilde’s 1897 nonfiction work De Profundis.

"People whose desire is solely for self-realisation never know where they are going. They can’t know. In one sense of the word it is of course necessary to know oneself: that is the first achievement of knowledge. But to recognise that the soul of a man is unknowable, is the ultimate achievement of wisdom. The final mystery is oneself. When one has weighed the sun in the balance, and measured the steps of the moon, and mapped out the seven heavens star by star, there still remains oneself. Who can calculate the orbit of his own soul?"
questions.question: Which choice best describes the function of the underlined question in the text as a whole?

options.A: It reinforces the text’s skepticism about the possibility of truly achieving self-knowledge.
options.B: It speculates that some readers will share the doubts expressed in the text about the value of self-knowledge.
options.C: It cautions readers that the text’s directions for how to achieve self-knowledge are hard to follow.
options.D: It concedes that the definition of self-knowledge advanced in the text is unpopular.

questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer because the rhetorical question 'Who can calculate the orbit of his own soul?' underlines the text's argument that true self-knowledge is an unattainable ideal, reinforcing the overall skepticism about the possibility of knowing oneself completely.

questions.text: For his 1986 album Keyboard Fantasies, Beverly Glenn-Copeland wrote songs grounded in traditional soul and folk music, then accompanied them with futuristic synthesizer arrangements featuring ambient sounds and complex rhythms. The result was so strange, so unprecedented, that the album attracted little attention when first released. In recent years, however, a younger generation of musicians has embraced the stylistic experimentation of Keyboard Fantasies. Alternative R&B musicians Blood Orange and Moses Sumney, among other contemporary recording artists, cite the album as an influence.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the function of the underlined sentence in the text as a whole?

options.A: It urges contemporary musicians to adopt the unique sound of Keyboard Fantasies.
options.B: It responds to criticism of Keyboard Fantasies by some younger musicians.
options.C: It offers examples of younger musicians whose work has been impacted by Keyboard Fantasies.
options.D: It contrasts Keyboard Fantasies with the recordings of two younger musicians.

questions.rationale: Choice C is the best answer because the underlined sentence provides specific examples—namely, Blood Orange and Moses Sumney—to illustrate that a younger generation of musicians has been influenced by Keyboard Fantasies, highlighting its eventual impact despite initial neglect.

questions.text: In most building demolitions, the building materials are destroyed and sent to landfills. City officials in Portland, Oregon, wanted to reduce this waste. The officials passed a law requiring demolition companies to deconstruct some buildings instead. Deconstruction involves carefully taking buildings apart piece by piece. Damage to the materials is avoided so that they can be reused in new constructions. A 2019 study found that 27 percent of materials from deconstructions in Portland were able to be reused. The remaining materials were processed for recycling instead of going to a landfill.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main purpose of the text?

options.A: To explain an effort made by the city of Portland to reduce demolition waste and some results of that effort
options.B: To show that popular support for measures that reduce demolition waste has increased since 2019
options.C: To argue that building deconstruction is not as effective as other measures at reducing demolition waste
options.D: To discuss laws aimed to reduce demolition waste in Portland and compare them to similar laws in other cities

questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer because the text explains how Portland implemented a law requiring deconstruction, describes how deconstruction works, and presents study data on the reuse of demolition materials—all aimed at reducing demolition waste.

questions.text: The fossil record suggests that mammoths went extinct around 11 thousand years ago. In a 2021 study of environmental DNA (eDNA)—genetic material shed into the environment by organisms—in the Arctic, Yucheng Wang and colleagues found mammoth eDNA in sedimentary layers formed millennia later, around 4 kyr ago. To account for this discrepancy, Joshua H. Miller and Carl Simpson proposed that arctic temperatures could preserve a mammoth carcass on the surface, allowing it to leach DNA into the environment, for several thousand years.
questions.question: Which choice best states how the researchers in the 2021 study explained the discrepancy between the fossil record and eDNA evidence?

options.A: They argued that arctic conditions might allow carcasses to remain on the surface for thousands of years, thus leaching DNA over an extended period.
options.B: They suggested that the fossil record is unreliable and that eDNA provides a more accurate timeline for extinction.
options.C: They claimed that environmental DNA from other species might have been misattributed to mammoths.
options.D: They proposed that the mammoth eDNA represents a later re-population of the species.

questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer because the researchers, Miller and Simpson, proposed that cold arctic conditions could preserve a mammoth carcass on the surface for an extended period, leading to prolonged leaching of DNA into the sedimentary layers, which accounts for the presence of mammoth eDNA millennia after their extinction.

questions.text:
The following text is from Charlotte Perkins Gilman’s 1910 poem “The Earth’s Entail.”

"No matter how we cultivate the land,
Taming the forest and the prairie free;
No matter how we irrigate the sand,
Making the desert blossom at command,
 We must always leave the borders of the sea;
 The immeasureable reaches
 Of the windy wave-wet beaches,
The million-mile-long margin of the sea."
questions.question: Which choice best describes the overall structure of the text?

options.A: The speaker argues against interfering with nature and then gives evidence supporting this interference.
options.B: The speaker presents an account of efforts to dominate nature and then cautions that such efforts are only temporary.
options.C: The speaker provides examples of an admirable way of approaching nature and then challenges that approach.
options.D: The speaker describes attempts to control nature and then offers a reminder that not all nature is controllable.

questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer because the poem contrasts human efforts to control nature—through cultivation, taming, and irrigation—with the vast, untamable expanse of the sea. It reminds us that despite our efforts, there remain elements of nature that are beyond our control.

questions.text: According to Indian economist and sociologist Radhakamal Mukerjee (1889–1968), the Eurocentric concepts that informed early twentieth-century social scientific methods—for example, the idea that all social relations are reducible to struggles between individuals—had little relevance for India. Making the social sciences more responsive to Indians’ needs, Mukerjee argued, required constructing analytical categories informed by India’s cultural and ecological circumstances. Mukerjee thus proposed the communalist “Indian village” as the ideal model on which to base Indian economic and social policy.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the overall structure of the text?

options.A: The text recounts Mukerjee’s early training in the social scientific disciplines and then lists social policies whose implementation Mukerjee oversaw.
options.B: The text mentions some of Mukerjee’s economic theories and then traces their impact on other Indian social scientists of the twentieth century.
options.C: The text presents Mukerjee’s critique of the social sciences and then provides an example of his attempts to address issues he identified in his critique.
options.D: The text explains an influential economic theory and then demonstrates how that theory was more important to Mukerjee’s work than other social scientists have acknowledged.

questions.rationale: Choice C is the best answer because the text first presents Mukerjee’s critique—that Eurocentric concepts are irrelevant for India—and then offers his proposed solution: the communalist ‘Indian village’ as an analytical model for Indian policy.

questions.text:
The following text is adapted from Holly Goldberg Sloan’s 2017 novel Short.

"More than two years ago my parents bought a piano from some people who were moving to Utah. Mom and Dad gave it to my brothers and me for Christmas. I had to act really happy because it was such a big present, but I pretty much hated the thing from the second it was carried into the hallway upstairs, which is right next to my bedroom. The piano glared at me. It was like a songbird in a cage. It wanted to be set free." ©2017 by Holly Goldberg Sloan
questions.question: Which choice best states the main purpose of the text?

options.A: To explain why the narrator always wanted a piano close to her bedroom.
options.B: To establish how the narrator feels about the piano.
options.C: To suggest that the narrator’s brothers are talented piano players.
options.D: To describe the event that led the narrator’s parents to buy a piano.

questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer because the text focuses on conveying the narrator’s negative feelings toward the piano, despite the expectation to be happy about it as a gift. The vivid descriptions (e.g., the piano ‘glared’ at her, and its comparison to a caged songbird) underscore her dislike and discomfort.

questions.text:
The following text is adapted from Etsu Inagaki Sugimoto’s 1925 memoir A Daughter of the Samurai. As a young woman, Sugimoto moved from feudal Japan to the United States.

"The standards of my own and my adopted country differed so widely in some ways, and my love for both lands was so sincere, that sometimes I had an odd feeling of standing upon a cloud in space, and gazing with measuring eyes upon two separate worlds. At first I was continually trying to explain, by Japanese standards, all the queer things that came every day before my surprised eyes; for no one seemed to know the origin or significance of even the most familiar customs, nor why they existed and were followed."
questions.question: Which choice best describes the main purpose of the text?

options.A: To convey the narrator’s experience of observing and making sense of differences between two cultures she embraces.
options.B: To establish the narrator’s hope of forming connections with new companions by sharing customs she learned as a child.
options.C: To reveal the narrator’s recognition that she is hesitant to ask questions about certain aspects of a culture she is newly encountering.
options.D: To emphasize the narrator’s wonder at discovering that the physical distance between two countries is greater than she had expected.

questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer because the narrator explains her dual love for her native Japan and her adopted country, the United States, while describing how she constantly tried to make sense of the cultural differences by explaining unfamiliar customs using Japanese standards. This illustrates her experience of observing and reconciling differences between the two cultures.

questions.text: In the Here and Now Storybook (1921), educator Lucy Sprague Mitchell advanced the then controversial idea that books for very young children should imitate how they use language, since toddlers, who cannot yet grasp narrative or abstract ideas, seek reassurance in verbal repetition and naming. The most enduring example of this idea is Margaret Wise Brown’s 1947 picture book Goodnight Moon, in which a young rabbit names the objects in his room as he drifts off to sleep. Scholars note that the book’s emphasis on repetition, rhythm, and nonsense rhyme speaks directly to Mitchell’s influence.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the overall structure of the text?

options.A: It outlines a debate between two authors of children’s literature and then traces how that debate shaped theories on early childhood education.
options.B: It summarizes an argument about how children’s literature should be evaluated and then discusses a contrasting view on that subject.
options.C: It lists the literary characteristics that are common to many classics of children’s literature and then indicates the narrative subjects that are most appropriate for young children.
options.D: It presents a philosophy about what material is most suitable for children’s literature and then describes a book influenced by that philosophy.

questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer because the text first presents Mitchell’s philosophy on what constitutes appropriate children’s literature—specifically, language that imitates the way toddlers speak—and then provides the example of Goodnight Moon as a book influenced by that philosophy.

questions.text:
The following text is from Indian Boyhood, a 1902 memoir by Ohiyesa (Charles A. Eastman), a Santee Dakota writer. In the text, Ohiyesa recalls how the women in his tribe harvested maple syrup.

"Now the women began to test the trees—moving leisurely among them, axe in hand, and striking a single quick blow, to see if the sap would appear. The trees, like people, have their individual characters; some were ready to yield up their life-blood, while others were more reluctant. Now one of the birchen basins was set under each tree, and a hardwood chip driven deep into the cut which the axe had made. From the corners of this chip—at first drop by drop, then more freely—the sap trickled into the little dishes."
questions.question: Which choice best describes the function of the underlined sentence in the text as a whole?

options.A: It portrays the range of personality traits displayed by the women as they work.
options.B: It foregrounds the beneficial relationship between humans and maple trees.
options.C: It demonstrates how human behavior can be influenced by the natural environment.
options.D: It elaborates on an aspect of the maple trees that the women evaluate.

questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer because the underlined sentence compares the maple trees to people by describing how some trees willingly yield sap while others are reluctant. This detail elaborates on the specific aspect (the trees’ individual 'characters' and their sap-yielding tendencies) that the women evaluate when harvesting maple syrup.

questions.text:
The following text is from Charlotte Forten Grimké’s 1888 poem “At Newport.”

"Oh, deep delight to watch the gladsome waves
Exultant leap upon the rugged rocks;
Ever repulsed, yet ever rushing on—
Filled with a life that will not know defeat;
To see the glorious hues of sky and sea.
The distant snowy sails, glide spirit like,
Into an unknown world, to feel the sweet
Enchantment of the sea thrill all the soul,
Clearing the clouded brain, making the heart
Leap joyous as it own bright, singing waves!"
questions.question: Which choice best describes the function of the underlined portion in the text as a whole?

options.A: It portrays the surroundings as an imposing and intimidating scene.
options.B: It characterizes the sea’s waves as a relentless and enduring force.
options.C: It conveys the speaker’s ambivalence about the natural world.
options.D: It draws a contrast between the sea’s waves and the speaker’s thoughts.

questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer because the underlined portion emphasizes that the sea’s waves are continuously repulsed yet always return, suggesting they are relentless and enduring. This characterization supports the poem’s overall depiction of nature’s persistent and unstoppable energy.

questions.text:
The following text is adapted from Charles Chesnutt’s 1899 short story “Mars Jeems’s Nightmare.” The narrator and his wife have recently moved to the southern United States, and Julius is their carriage driver.

"Julius was very useful when we moved to our new residence. He had a thorough knowledge of the neighborhood, was familiar with the roads and the watercourses, knew the qualities of the various soils and what they would produce, and where the best hunting and fishing were to be had. He was a marvelous hand in the management of horses and dogs."
questions.question: Which choice best states the main purpose of the text?

options.A: To compare the narrator’s reaction to a new home with his wife’s reaction
options.B: To give an example of Julius’s knowledge about soil
options.C: To show that the narrator and Julius often hunt and fish together
options.D: To explain different ways in which Julius was helpful
