questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer because the text describes multiple ways in which Julius was useful—his knowledge of the neighborhood, roads, watercourses, soils, as well as his skill in managing horses and dogs—thus explaining the various ways he helped the narrator and his wife adjust to their new residence.

questions.text: When ancient oak planks were unearthed during subway construction in Rome, Mauro Bernabei and his team examined the growth rings in the wood to determine where these planks came from. By comparing the growth rings on the planks to records of similar rings in oaks from Europe, the team could trace the wood to the Jura region of France, hundreds of kilometers from Rome. Because timber could only have been transported from distant Jura to Rome by boat, the team’s findings suggest the complexity of Roman trade routes.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the function of the underlined sentence in the text as a whole?

options.A: It presents a conclusion about Roman trade routes based on the team’s findings.
options.B: It questions how the team was able to conclude that the planks were used to build a boat.
options.C: It explains why the planks were made from oak rather than a different kind of wood.
options.D: It describes common methods used in Roman subway construction.

questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer because the underlined sentence draws a conclusion from the research findings: since timber from the Jura region could only have been transported by boat, it implies that the Roman trade routes were complex. This conclusion connects the evidence obtained from the growth rings to a broader historical implication regarding trade.

questions.text: Jackie Ormes’s Torchy Brown in Dixie to Harlem (1937–38) was the first comic strip by a Black woman to appear in a widely read newspaper. The strip tells the story of Torchy, a young woman who leaves Mississippi to become a performer in New York City. Torchy’s story reflects the experience of the Great Migration (1910–1970), when millions of Black Americans left the South in search of opportunities in other parts of the United States. Torchy Brown thus shows how Ormes used comics to comment humorously on issues affecting Black Americans, which she continued to do throughout her career.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main purpose of the text?

options.A: To show how Ormes’s Torchy Brown inspired other Black women to write comic strips in the 1930s
options.B: To illustrate how the subjects Ormes addressed in her comic strips changed over the course of her career
options.C: To give an example of how Ormes presented the experiences of Black Americans in her comic strips
options.D: To claim that several characters in Torchy Brown were based on people that Ormes knew personally

questions.rationale: Choice C is the best answer because the text describes how Torchy Brown reflects the experience of the Great Migration and demonstrates how Ormes used comics as a vehicle to humorously comment on issues affecting Black Americans.

questions.text: In Jane Austen’s novel Mansfield Park, an almost imperceptible smile from potential suitor Henry Crawford causes the protagonist Fanny Price to blush; her embarrassment grows when she suspects that he is aware of it. This moment—in which Fanny not only infers Henry’s mental state through his gestures, but also infers that he is drawing inferences about her mental state—illustrates what literary scholar George Butte calls 'deep intersubjectivity,' a technique for representing interactions between consciousnesses through which Austen’s novels derive much of their social and psychological drama.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the function of the underlined sentence in the text as a whole?

options.A: It states a claim about Austen’s skill at representing psychological complexity that is reinforced by an example presented in the following sentence.
options.B: It advances an interpretation of an Austen protagonist who is contrasted with protagonists from other Austen novels cited in the following sentence.
options.C: It describes a recurring theme in Austen’s novels that is the focus of a literary scholar’s analysis summarized in the following sentence.
options.D: It provides a synopsis of an interaction in an Austen novel that illustrates a literary concept discussed in the following sentence.

questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer because the underlined sentence summarizes an interaction from Mansfield Park that serves as an example of 'deep intersubjectivity,' thereby illustrating the literary concept discussed in the following explanation.

questions.text: Streams and rivers carry soil and rocks from one location to another. But there is another way for these geological materials to move. Scientists call this process 'aeolian transport.' In aeolian transport, winds move small particles of soil or rock over potentially great distances. Geologist Melisa Diaz and her team studied dust in Antarctica to find out if it was moved by aeolian transport. They discovered that the dust matched geological material in Australia. Aeolian transport had carried it from one continent to another, across thousands of miles of open ocean.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the function of the underlined portion in the text as a whole?

options.A: It presents Melisa Diaz’s remarks about difficulties that her team encountered.
options.B: It introduces a scientific term that is used in the discussion that follows.
options.C: It emphasizes the surprising nature of the findings that are presented.
options.D: It explains the difference between two kinds of geological material.

questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer because the underlined portion ('Scientists call this process “aeolian transport.”') introduces the technical term that frames the subsequent explanation of how winds move geological materials, thus serving as a definition for the discussion that follows.

questions.text: Space scientists Anna-Lisa Paul, Stephen M. Elardo, and Robert Ferl planted seeds of Arabidopsis thaliana in samples of lunar regolith—the surface material of the Moon—and, serving as a control group, in terrestrial soil. They found that while all the seeds germinated, the roots of the regolith-grown plants were stunted compared with those in the control group. Moreover, unlike the plants in the control group, the regolith-grown plants exhibited red pigmentation, reduced leaf size, and inhibited growth rates—indicators of stress that were corroborated by postharvest molecular analysis.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main purpose of the text?

options.A: It describes an experiment that addressed an unresolved question about the extent to which lunar regolith resembles terrestrial soils.
options.B: It compares two distinct methods of assessing indicators of stress in plants grown in a simulated lunar environment.
options.C: It presents evidence in support of the hypothesis that seed germination in lunar habitats is an unattainable goal.
options.D: It discusses the findings of a study that evaluated the effects of exposing a plant species to lunar soil conditions.

questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer because the text outlines an experiment in which the growth of Arabidopsis thaliana was compared between lunar regolith and terrestrial soil, revealing that while germination occurred in both conditions, the lunar-grown plants exhibited signs of stress. This clearly indicates that the main purpose is to discuss the study's findings on the effects of lunar soil on plant growth.

questions.text:
The following text is adapted from Etsu Inagaki Sugimoto’s 1925 memoir A Daughter of the Samurai. As a young woman, Sugimoto moved from feudal Japan to the United States.

"The standards of my own and my adopted country differed so widely in some ways, and my love for both lands was so sincere, that sometimes I had an odd feeling of standing upon a cloud in space, and gazing with measuring eyes upon two separate worlds. At first I was continually trying to explain, by Japanese standards, all the queer things that came every day before my surprised eyes; for no one seemed to know the origin or significance of even the most familiar customs, nor why they existed and were followed."
questions.question: Which choice best describes the main purpose of the text?

options.A: To convey the narrator’s experience of observing and making sense of differences between two cultures she embraces.
options.B: To establish the narrator’s hope of forming connections with new companions by sharing customs she learned as a child.
options.C: To reveal the narrator’s recognition that she is hesitant to ask questions about certain aspects of a culture she is newly encountering.
options.D: To emphasize the narrator’s wonder at discovering that the physical distance between two countries is greater than she had expected.

questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer because the narrator describes her simultaneous love for both Japan and the United States, and her experience of trying to explain the unfamiliar customs in the United States using the standards from her native culture. This conveys her effort to understand the differences between the two cultures that she embraces.

questions.text:
The following text is from the Here and Now Storybook (1921) by Lucy Sprague Mitchell. 

"Using NASA’s powerful James Webb Space Telescope (JWST), Mercedes López-Morales and colleagues measured the wavelengths of light traveling through the atmosphere of WASP-39b, an exoplanet, or planet outside our solar system. Different molecules absorb different wavelengths of light, and the wavelength measurements showed the presence of carbon dioxide (CO₂) in WASP-39b’s atmosphere. This finding not only offers the first decisive evidence of CO₂ in the atmosphere of an exoplanet but also illustrates the potential for future scientific breakthroughs held by the JWST."
questions.question: Which choice best describes the overall structure of the text?

options.A: It presents a theoretical concept, illustrates how the name of the concept has changed, and shows how the name has entered common usage.
options.B: It introduces a respected researcher, describes an aspect of his work, and suggests why the work is historically significant.
options.C: It names the company where an important mathematician worked, details the mathematician’s career at the company, and provides an example of the recognition he received there.
options.D: It mentions a paper, offers a summary of the paper’s findings, and presents a researcher’s commentary on the paper.

questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer because the text begins by introducing the work of Mercedes López-Morales and her colleagues using the JWST to detect CO₂ in an exoplanet's atmosphere, then explains the significance of that discovery. It thus combines an introduction of a respected research effort with an explanation of its historical significance.

questions.text:
The following text is adapted from Charlotte Perkins Gilman’s 1910 poem “The Earth’s Entail.”

"No matter how we cultivate the land,
Taming the forest and the prairie free;
No matter how we irrigate the sand,
Making the desert blossom at command,
 We must always leave the borders of the sea;
 The immeasureable reaches
 Of the windy wave-wet beaches,
The million-mile-long margin of the sea."
questions.question: Which choice best describes the overall structure of the text?

options.A: The speaker argues against interfering with nature and then gives evidence supporting this interference.
options.B: The speaker presents an account of efforts to dominate nature and then cautions that such efforts are only temporary.
options.C: The speaker provides examples of an admirable way of approaching nature and then challenges that approach.
options.D: The speaker describes attempts to control nature and then offers a reminder that not all nature is controllable.

questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer because the text first describes human efforts to control nature (cultivating, taming, and irrigating land) and then reminds us that no matter what we do, nature has uncontrollable aspects (the vast, untamable sea).

questions.text:
The following text is adapted from Oscar Wilde’s 1897 nonfiction work De Profundis.

"People whose desire is solely for self-realisation never know where they are going. They can’t know. In one sense of the word it is of course necessary to know oneself: that is the first achievement of knowledge. But to recognise that the soul of a man is unknowable, is the ultimate achievement of wisdom. The final mystery is oneself. When one has weighed the sun in the balance, and measured the steps of the moon, and mapped out the seven heavens star by star, there still remains oneself. Who can calculate the orbit of his own soul?"
questions.question: Which choice best describes the function of the underlined question in the text as a whole?

options.A: It reinforces the text’s skepticism about the possibility of truly achieving self-knowledge.
options.B: It speculates that some readers will share the doubts expressed in the text about the value of self-knowledge.
options.C: It cautions readers that the text’s directions for how to achieve self-knowledge are hard to follow.
options.D: It concedes that the definition of self-knowledge advanced in the text is unpopular.

questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer because the underlined question 'Who can calculate the orbit of his own soul?' emphasizes the idea that true self-knowledge is unattainable, reinforcing the text’s broader skepticism regarding the possibility of complete self-understanding.

questions.text:
The following text is adapted from Charles Chesnutt’s 1899 short story “Mars Jeems’s Nightmare.” The narrator and his wife have recently moved to the southern United States, and Julius is their carriage driver.

"Julius was very useful when we moved to our new residence. He had a thorough knowledge of the neighborhood, was familiar with the roads and the watercourses, knew the qualities of the various soils and what they would produce, and where the best hunting and fishing were to be had. He was a marvelous hand in the management of horses and dogs."
questions.question: Which choice best states the main purpose of the text?

options.A: To compare the narrator’s reaction to a new home with his wife’s reaction
options.B: To give an example of Julius’s knowledge about soil
options.C: To show that the narrator and Julius often hunt and fish together
options.D: To explain different ways in which Julius was helpful

questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer because the text enumerates various ways Julius helped the narrator and his wife by highlighting his extensive knowledge and skills, thereby emphasizing his overall usefulness during their move.

questions.text: When ancient oak planks were unearthed during subway construction in Rome, Mauro Bernabei and his team examined the growth rings in the wood to determine where these planks came from. By comparing the growth rings on the planks to records of similar rings in oaks from Europe, the team could trace the wood to the Jura region of France, hundreds of kilometers from Rome. Because timber could only have been transported from distant Jura to Rome by boat, the team’s findings suggest the complexity of Roman trade routes.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the function of the underlined sentence in the text as a whole?

options.A: It presents a conclusion about Roman trade routes based on the team’s findings.
options.B: It questions how the team was able to conclude that the planks were used to build a boat.
options.C: It explains why the planks were made from oak rather than a different kind of wood.
options.D: It describes common methods used in Roman subway construction.

questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer because the underlined sentence draws a conclusion from the research—since the wood must have been transported by boat from the Jura region, this implies that Roman trade routes were complex.

questions.text: For his 1986 album Keyboard Fantasies, Beverly Glenn-Copeland wrote songs grounded in traditional soul and folk music, then accompanied them with futuristic synthesizer arrangements featuring ambient sounds and complex rhythms. The result was so strange, so unprecedented, that the album attracted little attention when first released. In recent years, however, a younger generation of musicians has embraced the stylistic experimentation of Keyboard Fantasies. Alternative R&B musicians Blood Orange and Moses Sumney, among other contemporary recording artists, cite the album as an influence.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the function of the underlined sentence in the text as a whole?

options.A: It urges contemporary musicians to adopt the unique sound of Keyboard Fantasies.
options.B: It responds to criticism of Keyboard Fantasies by some younger musicians.
options.C: It offers examples of younger musicians whose work has been impacted by Keyboard Fantasies.
options.D: It contrasts Keyboard Fantasies with the recordings of two younger musicians.

questions.rationale: Choice C is the best answer because the underlined sentence cites specific examples of younger musicians (Blood Orange and Moses Sumney) who have been influenced by the album, illustrating its impact despite initial neglect.

questions.text:
The following text is adapted from Holly Goldberg Sloan’s 2017 novel Short.

"More than two years ago my parents bought a piano from some people who were moving to Utah. Mom and Dad gave it to my brothers and me for Christmas. I had to act really happy because it was such a big present, but I pretty much hated the thing from the second it was carried into the hallway upstairs, which is right next to my bedroom. The piano glared at me. It was like a songbird in a cage. It wanted to be set free." ©2017 by Holly Goldberg Sloan
questions.question: Which choice best states the main purpose of the text?

options.A: To explain why the narrator always wanted a piano close to her bedroom.
options.B: To establish how the narrator feels about the piano.
options.C: To suggest that the narrator’s brothers are talented piano players.
options.D: To describe the event that led the narrator’s parents to buy a piano.

questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer because the text focuses on the narrator’s inner reaction to the piano, revealing that she was forced to feign happiness despite hating it, which establishes her true feelings about the instrument.

questions.text:
The following text is from Charlotte Perkins Gilman’s 1910 poem “The Earth’s Entail.”

"No matter how we cultivate the land,
Taming the forest and the prairie free;
No matter how we irrigate the sand,
Making the desert blossom at command,
 We must always leave the borders of the sea;
 The immeasureable reaches
 Of the windy wave-wet beaches,
The million-mile-long margin of the sea."
questions.question: Which choice best describes the overall structure of the text?

options.A: The speaker argues against interfering with nature and then gives evidence supporting this interference.
options.B: The speaker presents an account of efforts to dominate nature and then cautions that such efforts are only temporary.
options.C: The speaker provides examples of an admirable way of approaching nature and then challenges that approach.
options.D: The speaker describes attempts to control nature and then offers a reminder that not all nature is controllable.

questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer because the poem juxtaposes human efforts to control nature (cultivating, taming, irrigating) with the vast, uncontrollable nature of the sea, reminding the reader that certain natural forces remain beyond human influence.

questions.text: Space scientists Anna-Lisa Paul, Stephen M. Elardo, and Robert Ferl planted seeds of Arabidopsis thaliana in samples of lunar regolith—the surface material of the Moon—and, serving as a control group, in terrestrial soil. They found that while all the seeds germinated, the roots of the regolith-grown plants were stunted compared with those in the control group. Moreover, unlike the plants in the control group, the regolith-grown plants exhibited red pigmentation, reduced leaf size, and inhibited growth rates—indicators of stress that were corroborated by postharvest molecular analysis.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main purpose of the text?

options.A: It describes an experiment that addressed an unresolved question about the extent to which lunar regolith resembles terrestrial soils.
options.B: It compares two distinct methods of assessing indicators of stress in plants grown in a simulated lunar environment.
options.C: It presents evidence in support of the hypothesis that seed germination in lunar habitats is an unattainable goal.
options.D: It discusses the findings of a study that evaluated the effects of exposing a plant species to lunar soil conditions.

questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer because the text outlines an experiment that compares plant growth in lunar regolith with that in terrestrial soil, and then discusses the resulting indicators of stress, thereby evaluating the impact of lunar soil conditions on plant development.

questions.text: Raymond Antrobus, an accomplished poet and writer of prose, recently released his debut spoken word poetry album, The First Time I Wore Hearing Aids, in collaboration with producer Ian Brennan. The album contains both autobiographical and reflective pieces combining Antrobus’s spoken words with Brennan’s fragmented audio elements and pieces of music to convey how people who are deaf may experience sound, both its presence and absence. Some critics suggest that the album questions the function of sound in the world, highlighting that the experience of sound is multifaceted.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the overall structure of the text?

options.A: It introduces a collaborative spoken word poetry project, details the approach taken to produce the work, and then provides an example of critique the album received upon release.
options.B: It mentions a collection of spoken word poems, distinguishes one poem as being an exemplar on the album, and then offers a summary of the subject matter of the whole collection.
options.C: It summarizes the efforts to produce a collection of spoken word poems, presents biographies of two people who worked on the album, and speculates about the meaning behind the poetry.
options.D: It connects two artists to the same spoken word poetry project, explains the extent of their collaboration on each poem, and then provides an overview of the technique used to produce the work.

questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer because the text begins by introducing the collaborative spoken word album by Raymond Antrobus and Ian Brennan, describes the innovative approach taken in combining spoken word with fragmented audio and musical elements, and concludes by noting that some critics interpret the album as questioning the function of sound, thereby providing a full structural overview.

questions.text:
The following text is from Sarah Orne Jewett’s 1899 short story “Martha’s Lady.” Martha is employed by Miss Pyne as a maid.
Miss Pyne sat by the window watching, in her best dress, looking stately and calm; she seldom went out now, and it was almost time for the carriage. Martha was just coming in from the garden with the strawberries, and with more flowers in her apron. It was a bright cool evening in June, the golden robins sang in the elms, and the sun was going down behind the apple-trees at the foot of the garden. The beautiful old house stood wide open to the long-expected guest.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main purpose of the text?

options.A: To convey the worries brought about by a new guest
options.B: To describe how the characters have changed over time
options.C: To contrast the activity indoors with the stillness outside
options.D: To depict the setting as the characters await a visitor’s arrival

questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer because the text provides descriptive details of the surroundings and the characters’ behavior that together convey the anticipation of the long-expected guest's arrival.

questions.text: Many films from the early 1900s have been lost. These losses include several films by the first wave of Black women filmmakers. We know about these lost movies only from small pieces of evidence. For example, an advertisement for Jennie Louise Touissant Welcome’s documentary Doing Their Bit still exists. There’s a reference in a magazine to Tressie Souders’s film A Woman’s Error. And Maria P. Williams’s The Flames of Wrath is mentioned in a letter and a newspaper article, and one image from the movie was discovered in the 1990s.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the overall structure of the text?

options.A: The text identifies a complex problem, then presents examples of unsuccessful attempts to solve that problem.
options.B: The text summarizes a debate among researchers, then gives reasons for supporting one side in that debate.
options.C: The text describes a general situation, then illustrates that situation with specific examples.
options.D: The text discusses several notable individuals, then explains commonly overlooked differences between those individuals.

questions.rationale: Choice C is the best answer because the text first outlines the general situation—that many early films, including those by Black women filmmakers, have been lost—and then provides specific examples of the limited pieces of evidence that inform us about those lost films.

questions.passage:
I HEAR it is charged against me that I seek to destroy institutions;
But really I am neither for nor against institutions
(What indeed have I in common with them?—Or what with the destruction of them?),
Only I will establish in the Mannahatta [Manhattan] and in every city of These States, inland and seaboard,
And in the fields and woods, and above every keel [ship] little or large, that dents the water,
Without edifices, or rules, or trustees, or any argument,
The institution of the dear love of comrades.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the overall structure of the text?

options.A: The speaker questions an increasingly prevalent attitude, then summarizes his worldview.
options.B: The speaker regrets his isolation from others, then predicts a profound change in society.
options.C: The speaker concedes his personal shortcomings, then boasts of his many achievements.
options.D: The speaker addresses a criticism leveled against him, then announces a grand ambition of his.

questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer because it best describes the overall structure of the text. The speaker begins by stating that he has heard that others are accusing him of seeking to destroy institutions. He then addresses this criticism by clarifying that he is neither for nor against institutions while ultimately stating his goal of establishing the institution of the dear love of comrades everywhere.

questions.passage: Hiroshi Senju is known worldwide for his paintings of waterfalls. These paintings are large and tend not to show the entire waterfall. Instead, Senju focuses on just the point where the falling water reaches the pool below, keeping the top of the waterfall out of view. While Senju’s paintings are rooted in art movements originating in the United States, the artist uses traditional Japanese techniques and materials that make his work instantly recognizable.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the overall structure of the text?

options.A: It introduces an artist and then explains some common characteristics of well-known paintings by that artist.
options.B: It explains a specific painting technique and then provides examples of artists who use the technique.
options.C: It describes a famous painting and then compares it to a lesser-known painting from the same time period.
options.D: It gives an opinion on an artist and then suggests multiple reasons why the artist’s work has been largely overlooked.

questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer. The text starts by introducing Senju as a famous artist and then describes the defining features of his work, including his focus on a specific part of the waterfall and his incorporation of both American art movements and traditional Japanese techniques.

questions.passage: In 1801, a Blackfoot chief named Ac Ko Mok Ki drew a finely detailed map of the Upper Missouri region. This work demonstrates a vast amount of topographic knowledge, as the map features specific names of mountains and rivers, as well as the first-known sketch of the drainage network of the Missouri River. The map is especially notable because Ac Ko Mok Ki also included details about the numerous tribes that lived in the area.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the function of the underlined sentence in the text as a whole?

options.A: It emphasizes Ac Ko Mok Ki’s desire to represent other tribes on the map.
options.B: It explains how Ac Ko Mok Ki developed an interest in mapmaking.
options.C: It identifies some reasons why the map is impressive.
options.D: It details how the map was used for hunting and trading purposes.

questions.rationale: Choice C is the best answer because the underlined sentence explains that the map demonstrates a vast amount of topographic knowledge by listing features such as mountain and river names and the drainage network. This supports the idea that the map is impressive due to these detailed characteristics.

questions.passage: In many agricultural environments, the banks of streams are kept forested to protect water quality, but it’s been unclear what effects these forests may have on stream biodiversity. To investigate the issue, biologist Xingli Giam and colleagues studied an Indonesian oil palm plantation, comparing the species richness of forested streams with that of nonforested streams. Giam and colleagues found that species richness was significantly higher in forested streams, a finding the researchers attribute to the role leaf litter plays in sheltering fish from predators and providing food resources.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main purpose of the text?

options.A: It discusses research intended to settle a debate about how agricultural yields can be increased without negative effects on water quality.
options.B: It explains the differences between stream-protection strategies used in oil palm plantations and stream-protection strategies used in other kinds of agricultural environments.
options.C: It describes findings that challenge a previously held view about how fish that inhabit streams in agricultural environments attempt to avoid predators.
options.D: It presents a study that addresses an unresolved question about the presence of forests along streams in agricultural environments.

questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer because the text begins by presenting an unresolved question regarding the effect of bank forests on stream biodiversity and then discusses a study that provides evidence that forested streams have higher species richness.

questions.passage: Works of moral philosophy, such as Plato’s Republic or Aristotle’s Nicomachean Ethics, are partly concerned with how to live a morally good life. But philosopher Jonathan Barnes argues that works that present a method of living such a life without also supplying a motive are inherently useful only to those already wishing to be morally good—those with no desire for moral goodness will not choose to follow their rules. However, some works of moral philosophy attempt to describe what constitutes a morally good life while also proposing reasons for living one.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the overall structure of the text?

options.A: It provides a characterization about a field of thought by noting two works in it and then details a way in which some works in that field are more comprehensive than others.
options.B: It mentions two renowned works and then claims that despite their popularity it is impossible for these works to serve the purpose their authors intended.
options.C: It summarizes the history of a field of thought by discussing two works and then proposes a topic of further research for specialists in that field.
options.D: It describes two influential works and then explains why one is more widely read than the other.

questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer. The text begins by stating what moral philosophy is concerned with and citing two classic works. It then explains a limitation in some works that only prescribe how to live morally good lives without providing a motive, before noting that other works address this shortcoming.

questions.passage: Industrial activity is often assumed to be a threat to wildlife, but that isn’t always so. Consider the silver-studded blue butterfly (Plebejus argus): as forest growth has reduced grasslands in northern Germany, many of these butterflies have left meadow habitats and are now thriving in active limestone quarries. In a survey of multiple active quarries and patches of maintained grassland, an ecologist found silver-studded blue butterflies in 100% of the quarries but only 57% of the grassland patches. Moreover, butterfly populations in the quarries were four times larger than those in the meadows.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the function of the underlined portion in the text as a whole?

options.A: It challenges a common assumption about the species under investigation in the research referred to in the text.
options.B: It introduces discussion of a specific example that supports the general claim made in the previous sentence.
options.C: It suggests that a certain species should be included in additional studies like the one mentioned later in the text.
options.D: It provides a definition for an unfamiliar term that is central to the main argument in the text.

questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer because the underlined portion serves to introduce a specific example—the silver-studded blue butterfly in limestone quarries—that supports the general claim that industrial activity is not always a threat to wildlife.

questions.passage:
The following text is from Lucy Maud Montgomery’s 1908 novel Anne of Green Gables. Anne, an eleven-year-old girl, has come to live on a farm with a woman named Marilla in Nova Scotia, Canada.
Anne reveled in the world of color about her.
“Oh, Marilla,” she exclaimed one Saturday morning, coming dancing in with her arms full of gorgeous boughs, “I’m so glad I live in a world where there are Octobers. It would be terrible if we just skipped from September to November, wouldn’t it? Look at these maple branches. Don’t they give you a thrill—several thrills? I’m going to decorate my room with them.”
“Messy things,” said Marilla, whose aesthetic sense was not noticeably developed. “You clutter up your room entirely too much with out-of-the-doors stuff, Anne. Bedrooms were made to sleep in.”
questions.question: Which choice best states the main purpose of the text?

options.A: To demonstrate that Anne has a newly developed appreciation of nature
options.B: To describe an argument that Anne and Marilla often have
options.C: To emphasize Marilla’s disapproval of how Anne has decorated her room
options.D: To show that Anne and Marilla have very different personalities

questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer because it most accurately describes the main purpose of the text. The text begins by noting that Anne 'reveled in the world of color about her'—that is, she takes great delight in colorful things. It then relates a scene when she enthusiastically enters the house with autumn foliage and announces that she will decorate her room with it. The focus of the text then shifts to Marilla, who has an undeveloped 'aesthetic sense,' as shown when she dismisses the maple leaves as 'messy things' and criticizes Anne for cluttering her room with outdoor objects. This episode illustrates that Anne and Marilla have very different personalities.

questions.passage:
The following text is adapted from Aphra Behn’s 1689 novel The Lucky Mistake. Atlante and Rinaldo are neighbors who have been secretly exchanging letters through Charlot, Atlante’s sister.
[Atlante] gave this letter to Charlot; who immediately ran into the balcony with it, where she still found Rinaldo in a melancholy posture, leaning his head on his hand: She showed him the letter, but was afraid to toss it to him, for fear it might fall to the ground; so he ran and fetched a long cane, which he cleft at one end, and held it while she put the letter into the cleft, and stayed not to hear what he said to it. But never was man so transported with joy, as he was at the reading of this letter; it gives him new wounds; for to the generous, nothing obliges love so much as love.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the overall structure of the text?

options.A: It describes the delivery of a letter, and then portrays a character’s happiness at reading that letter.
options.B: It establishes that a character is desperate to receive a letter, and then explains why another character has not yet written that letter.
options.C: It presents a character’s concerns about delivering a letter, and then details the contents of that letter.
options.D: It reveals the inspiration behind a character’s letter, and then emphasizes the excitement that another character feels upon receiving that letter.

questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer because it most accurately describes the overall structure of the text. The narrator explains how Charlot carefully delivers Atlante’s letter to Rinaldo, then relates that Rinaldo is 'transported with joy' upon reading it.

questions.passage: Genetic studies have led researchers to suggest that turtles are most closely related to the group that includes modern crocodiles. But studies of fossils have suggested instead that turtles are most closely related to other groups, such as the one that contains modern snakes. However, many of the fossil studies have relied on incomplete data sets. For a 2022 investigation, biologist Tiago R. Simões and colleagues examined more than 1,000 reptile fossils collected worldwide. From this large data set, they found clear agreement with the results of the genetic studies.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the function of the underlined sentence?

options.A: It offers an overview of the tools scientists use to examine fossils.
options.B: It describes a limitation of some studies about the origin of turtles.
options.C: It summarizes previous research on the evolution of crocodiles.
options.D: It criticizes a widely held belief about genetic studies of reptiles.

questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer. The sentence points out that many fossil studies have relied on incomplete data sets, thereby describing a limitation of those studies in understanding turtle origins.

questions.passage:
The following text is adapted from Gwendolyn Bennett’s 1926 poem “Street Lamps in Early Spring.”
Night wears a garment
All velvet soft, all violet blue... 
And over her face she draws a veil
As shimmering fine as floating dew... 
And here and there
In the black of her hair
The subtle hands of Night
Move slowly with their gem-starred light.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the overall structure of the text?

options.A: It presents alternating descriptions of night in a rural area and in a city.
options.B: It sketches an image of nightfall, then an image of sunrise.
options.C: It makes an extended comparison of night to a human being.
options.D: It portrays how night changes from one season of the year to the next.

questions.rationale: Choice C is the best answer because the text characterizes night by comparing it to a human being—describing clothing, a veil, and hands moving slowly—which is an extended comparison of night to a human.

questions.passage:
The following text is adapted from Susan Glaspell’s 1912 short story 'Out There.' An elderly shop owner is looking at a picture that he recently acquired and hopes to sell.
It did seem that the picture failed to fit in with the rest of the shop. A persuasive young fellow who claimed he was closing out his stock let the old man have it for what he called a song. It was only a little out-of-the-way store which subsisted chiefly on the framing of pictures. The old man looked around at his views of the city, his pictures of cats and dogs, his flaming bits of landscape. 'Don’t belong in here,' he fumed.
And yet the old man was secretly proud of his acquisition. There was a hidden dignity in his scowling as he shuffled about pondering the least ridiculous place for the picture.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main purpose of the text?

options.A: To reveal the shop owner’s conflicted feelings about the new picture
options.B: To convey the shop owner’s resentment of the person he got the new picture from
options.C: To describe the items that the shop owner most highly prizes
options.D: To explain differences between the new picture and other pictures in the shop

questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer because the text reveals the shop owner’s conflicted feelings about the new picture. While he criticizes its lack of fit with the rest of his shop, he is also secretly proud of having acquired it.

questions.passage:
The following text is from Herman Melville’s 1854 novel The Lightning-rod Man.
The stranger still stood in the exact middle of the cottage, where he had first planted himself. His singularity impelled a closer scrutiny. A lean, gloomy figure. Hair dark and lank, mattedly streaked over his brow. His sunken pitfalls of eyes were ringed by indigo halos, and played with an innocuous sort of lightning: the gleam without the bolt. The whole man was dripping. He stood in a puddle on the bare oak floor: his strange walking-stick vertically resting at his side.
questions.question: Which choice best states the function of the underlined sentence in the overall structure of the text?

options.A: It elaborates on the previous sentence’s description of the character.
options.B: It introduces the setting that is described in the sentences that follow.
options.C: It establishes a contrast with the description in the previous sentence.
options.D: It sets up the character description presented in the sentences that follow.

The underlined sentence essentially indicates that the character stands out, prompting a closer look, and sets up the detailed character description that follows. It does not elaborate on the previous description, introduce the setting, or establish any contrast.

questions.passage: Many archaeologists assume that large-scale engineering projects in ancient societies required an elite class to plan and direct the necessary labor. However, recent discoveries, such as the excavation of an ancient canal near the Gulf Coast of Alabama, have complicated this picture. Using radiocarbon dating, a team of researchers concluded that the 1.39-kilometer-long canal was most likely constructed between 576 and 650 CE by an Indigenous society that was relatively free of social classes.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the overall structure of the text?

options.A: It describes a common view among archaeologists, then discusses a recent finding that challenges that view.
options.B: It outlines a method used in some archaeological fieldwork, then explains why an alternative method is superior to it.
options.C: It presents contradictory conclusions drawn by archaeologists, then evaluates a study that has apparently resolved that contradiction.
options.D: It identifies a gap in scientific research, then presents a strategy used by some archaeologists to remedy that gap.

questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer. The text starts by presenting a common view among archaeologists regarding the necessity of an elite class for large-scale engineering projects and then introduces a recent discovery that challenges this assumption by showing that an Indigenous society, without a defined elite class, built a canal.

questions.passage: The 1967 release of Harold Cruse’s book The Crisis of the Negro Intellectual isolated him from almost all other scholars and activists of the American Civil Rights Movement—though many of those thinkers disagreed with each other, he nonetheless found ways to disagree with them all. He thought that activists who believed that Black people such as himself should culturally assimilate were naïve. But he also sharply criticized Black nationalists such as Marcus Garvey who wanted to establish independent, self-contained Black economies and societies, even though Cruse himself identified as a Black nationalist.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the function of the underlined sentence in the text as a whole?

options.A: It describes a direction that Cruse felt the Civil Rights Movement ought to take.
options.B: It indicates that Cruse’s reputation as a persistent antagonist of other scholars is undeserved.
options.C: It describes a controversy that Cruse’s work caused within the Black nationalist movement.
options.D: It helps explain Cruse’s position with respect to the community of civil rights thinkers.

questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer. The underlined sentence clarifies Cruse's complex position by showing that he not only criticized assimilationist activists but also harshly critiqued Black nationalists, despite identifying as one himself. This helps explain his overall stance in relation to the broader community of civil rights thinkers.

questions.passage: Artist Marilyn Dingle’s intricate, coiled baskets are ______blank sweetgrass and palmetto palm. Following a Gullah technique that originated in West Africa, Dingle skillfully winds a thin palm frond around a bunch of sweetgrass with the help of a “sewing bone” to create the basket’s signature look that no factory can reproduce.

In this context, stating that the baskets are 'handmade from' sweetgrass and palmetto palm indicates that Dingle creates the baskets herself using those specific plants without machine production. The passage emphasizes the artisan quality of her work that 'no factory can reproduce.'

questions.passage:
The following text is adapted from Nathaniel Hawthorne’s 1837 story “Dr. Heidegger’s Experiment.” The main character, a physician, is experimenting with rehydrating a dried flower.
At first [the rose] lay lightly on the surface of the fluid, appearing to imbibe none of its moisture. Soon, however, a singular change began to be visible. The crushed and dried petals stirred and assumed a deepening tinge of crimson, as if the flower were reviving from a deathlike slumber.
questions.question: As used in the text, what does the phrase “a singular” most nearly mean?

options.A: a lonely
options.B: a disagreeable
options.C: an acceptable
options.D: an extraordinary

questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer because in this context 'singular' most nearly means extraordinary. The passage describes an unusual and striking transformation in the rose as it rehydrates, making the change seem exceptional and remarkable.

questions.passage: Rejecting the premise that the literary magazine Ebony and Topaz (1927) should present a unified vision of Black American identity, editor Charles S. Johnson fostered his contributors’ diverse perspectives by promoting their authorial autonomy. Johnson’s self-effacement diverged from the editorial stances of W.E.B. Du Bois and Alain Locke, whose decisions for their publications were more ______blank.

options.B: dogmatic
options.C: ambiguous
options.D: unpretentious

questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer. In the context provided, Du Bois and Locke are portrayed as having a more fixed, unified vision about Black American identity, implying they held their views with a firmness that can be described as 'dogmatic'. Johnson, in contrast, promoted diversity of perspectives.

questions.passage: Some economic historians ______blank that late nineteenth- and early twentieth-century households in the United States experienced an economy of scale when it came to food purchases—they assumed that large households spent less on food per person than did small households. Economist Trevon Logan showed, however, that a close look at the available data disproves this supposition.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.A: surmised
options.B: contrived
options.C: questioned
options.D: regretted

questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer because 'surmised' means to form an idea or assumption with little evidence, which fits the context where economic historians assumed that larger households spent less on food per person. The passage contrasts this assumption with Logan's data-driven findings that disprove it.

questions.passage:
The following text is from Bram Stoker’s 1897 novel Dracula. The narrator is being driven in a carriage through a remote region at night.

The baying of the wolves sounded nearer and nearer, as though they were closing round on us from every side. I grew dreadfully afraid, and the horses shared my fear. The driver, however, was not in the least disturbed; he kept turning his head to left and right, but I could not see anything through the darkness.
questions.question: As used in the text, what does the word “disturbed” most nearly mean?

options.A: Disorganized
options.B: Alarmed
options.C: Offended
options.D: Interrupted

questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer because as used in the text, 'disturbed' most nearly means alarmed. The passage contrasts the narrator and the horses, who are 'dreadfully afraid', with the driver who remains calm and unalarmed by the eerie sounds, indicating that he is not 'disturbed' (i.e., not alarmed) by the presence of the wolves.

questions.passage: Economist Marco Castillo and colleagues showed that nuisance costs—the time and effort people must spend to make donations—reduce charitable giving. Charities can mitigate this effect by compensating donors for nuisance costs, but those costs, though variable, are largely ______blank donation size, so charities that compensate donors will likely favor attracting a few large donors over many small donors.

options.A: supplemental to
options.B: predictive of
options.C: independent of
options.D: subsumed in

questions.rationale: Choice C is the best answer because the context explains that nuisance costs affect donor behavior regardless of the donation amount. They are not linked to (or determined by) donation size, meaning they are 'independent of' donation size. This independence is why charities compensating for such costs would likely attract a few large donors rather than many small ones.

questions.passage: During a 2014 archaeological dig in Spain, Vicente Lull and his team uncovered the skeleton of a woman from El Algar, an Early Bronze Age society, buried with valuable objects signaling a high position of power. This finding may persuade researchers who have argued that Bronze Age societies were ruled by men to ______blank that women may have also held leadership roles.

options.A: waive
options.B: concede
options.C: refute
options.D: require

questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer. The context indicates that some researchers assert that only men ruled Bronze Age societies. However, the discovery of a high-status female burial may cause these researchers to 'concede'—or admit—the possibility that women also held leadership roles.

questions.passage: Dance choreographer Jawole Willa Jo Zollar aims to give people the opportunity to be ______blank her creative process. For example, live performances of her dance HairStories, which debuted in 2001, featured videos of people across the United States talking about their hair and audience members sharing pictures of their interesting hairstyles.

options.A: nervous about
options.B: completed by
options.C: delayed by
options.D: involved in

questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer because 'involved in' means to actively participate, which fits the context of Zollar including audience contributions in her creative process, as evidenced by incorporating audience videos and pictures in her performances.

questions.passage:
The following text is adapted from Nathaniel Hawthorne’s 1844 short story 'Drowne’s Wooden Image.' Drowne, a young man, is carving a wooden figure to decorate the front of a ship.

options.A: Acquired
options.B: Acknowledged

questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer because in this context 'assumed' means that the work gradually 'acquired' greater precision. As Drowne carves, the once indistinct figure becomes increasingly clear and defined, as if it has come to possess or acquired more precision.

questions.passage: Former astronaut Ellen Ochoa says that although she doesn’t have a definite idea of when it might happen, she ______blank that humans will someday need to be able to live in other environments than those found on Earth. questions.passage: A musician and member of the Quechua of Peru, Renata Flores Rivera was eager to promote the Quechua language in her music, but she was ______blank speaking it. questions.passage: Seminole/Muscogee director Sterlin Harjo ______blank television’s tendency to situate Native characters in the distant past: this rejection is evident in his series Reservation Dogs, which revolves around teenagers who dress in contemporary styles and whose dialogue is laced with current slang.

questions.passage:

questions.passage: According to botanists, a viburnum plant experiencing insect damage may develop erineum—a discolored, felty growth—on its leaf blades. A ______blank viburnum plant, on the other hand, will have leaves with smooth surfaces and uniformly green coloration.

questions.passage: Research conducted by planetary scientist Katarina Miljkovic suggests that the Moon’s surface may not accurately ______blank early impact events. questions.passage: Charles “Teenie” Harris was a photographer for the Pittsburgh Courier from 1936 to 1975. questions.passage:

[Mr. Brooke] had travelled in his younger years, and was held in this part of the country to have contracted a too rambling habit of mind. Mr. Brooke’s conclusions were as difficult to predict as the weather.

questions.passage: Although science fiction was dominated mostly by white male authors when Octavia Butler, a Black woman, began writing, she did not view the genre as ______blank: Butler broke into the field with the publication of several short stories and her 1976 novel Patternmaster, and she later became the first science fiction writer to win a prestigious MacArthur Fellowship.

options.A: legitimate

questions.passage: In the 1970s, video cameras became increasingly affordable for ordinary consumers and gave Ulysses Jenkins and other artists capabilities that were previously unavailable except to television broadcasters. Jenkins recognized and took full advantage of this ______blank access to powerful technology to create groundbreaking works of video art, such as Mass of Images (1978).
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.A: newfound

Tohru Ikeguchi uses open-source data and statistical modeling to identify when a high number of users making one-way trips is likely to leave some locations within the system ______blank bicycles and other areas with insufficient supply.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.A: susceptible to
options.B: contingent on
options.C: saturated with
options.D: depleted of

questions.rationale: Choice C is correct because 'saturated with' means completely filled or supplied. The passage explains that when many users make one-way trips, some locations end up with an excess of bicycles while others suffer from an insufficient supply.

questions.passage: Osage Nation citizen Randy Tinker-Smith produced and directed the ballet Wahzhazhe, which vividly chronicles Osage history and culture. Telling Osage stories through ballet is ______blank choice because two of the foremost ballet dancers of the twentieth century were Osage: sisters Maria and Marjorie Tallchief.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.A: a suitable
options.B: a determined
options.C: an arbitrary
options.D: an unpredictable

questions.rationale: Choice A is correct because 'a suitable' means appropriate. The fact that two of the foremost ballet dancers were Osage supports the idea that using ballet to tell Osage stories is a fitting and appropriate artistic choice.

questions.passage: In the Indigenous intercropping system known as the Three Sisters, maize, squash, and beans form an ______blank web of relations: maize provides the structure on which the bean vines grow; the squash vines cover the soil, discouraging competition from weeds; and the beans aid their two 'sisters' by enriching the soil with essential nitrogen.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.A: indecipherable
options.B: ornamental
options.C: obscure
options.D: intricate

questions.rationale: Choice D is correct because 'intricate' means complexly interrelated. This accurately reflects the detailed and mutually supportive relationships among the Three Sisters crops as described in the text.

questions.passage: The printing of Virginia Woolf’s novels featured a creative ______blank between Woolf and her sister Vanessa Bell: a talented painter, Bell worked closely with Woolf to create original cover art for most of the novels.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.A: rebellion
options.B: partnership
options.C: discovery
options.D: disagreement

questions.rationale: Choice B is correct because 'partnership' implies a collaborative relationship. The text describes how Vanessa Bell and Virginia Woolf worked closely together on creating cover art, which is a clear example of a creative partnership.

questions.passage: Anthropologist Kristian J. Carlson and colleagues examined the fossilized clavicle and shoulder bones of a 3.6-million-year-old early hominin known as 'Little Foot.' They found that these bones were ______blank the clavicle and shoulder bones of modern apes that are frequent climbers, such as gorillas and chimpanzees, suggesting that Little Foot had adapted to life in the trees.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.A: surpassed by
options.B: comparable to
options.C: independent of
options.D: obtained from

questions.rationale: Choice B is correct because 'comparable to' means similar to or on par with. The passage indicates that the structure of Little Foot’s bones is similar to that of modern climbing apes, which suggests a comparable adaptation to arboreal life.

questions.passage:
The following text is adapted from Oscar Wilde’s 1895 play The Importance of Being Earnest.

CECILY: Have we got to part?
ALGERNON: I am afraid so. It’s a very painful parting.
CECILY: It is always painful to part from people whom one has known for a very brief space of time. The absence of old friends one can endure with equanimity. But even a momentary separation from anyone to whom one has just been introduced is almost unbearable.
questions.question: As used in the text, what does the word 'endure' most nearly mean?

options.A: Regret
options.B: Persist
options.C: Tolerate
options.D: Encourage

questions.rationale: Choice C is correct because in this context 'endure' means to tolerate. Cecily contrasts the relative ease with which one can tolerate the absence of long-known friends with the severe discomfort caused by parting from a new acquaintance.

questions.passage: In discussing the OSIRIS-REx spacecraft’s encounter with asteroid 101955 Bennu, the text explains that despite unforeseen problems due to boulders on the asteroid’s surface, the spacecraft was able to gather a sample to return to Earth.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase describing what OSIRIS-REx did?

options.A: attached
options.B: collected
options.C: followed
options.D: replaced

questions.rationale: Choice B is correct because 'collected' means to gather or acquire. The passage indicates that OSIRIS-REx successfully gathered a sample from the asteroid, despite the challenges encountered.

questions.passage: The parasitic dodder plant increases its reproductive success by flowering at the same time as the host plant it has latched onto. In 2020, Jianqiang Wu and his colleagues determined that the tiny dodder achieves this ______blank with its host by absorbing and utilizing a protein the host produces when it is about to flower.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.A: synchronization
options.B: hibernation
options.C: prediction
options.D: moderation

questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer because, in this context, 'synchronization' refers to the process of matching the timing of flowering between the dodder and its host. The dodder absorbs a protein produced by the host just before it flowers, allowing the dodder to flower at the same time—achieving synchronization.

questions.passage: Sumerian civilization (which lasted from around 3300 to 2000 BCE) ______blank many concepts that persist into present-day civilizations: for example, the first description of the seven-day week appears in the Sumerian Epic of Gilgamesh.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.A: transformed
options.B: introduced
options.C: inherited
options.D: overlooked

questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer because 'introduced' means to bring into use for the first time. The passage describes how Sumerian civilization originated ideas—like the seven-day week—that continue to be used today.

questions.passage: Physicist Joseph Weber performed ______blank work in gravitational wave research in the 1960s and 1970s, conducting key experiments that scientists later used as the basis for their own investigations that led to the first verified detection of a gravitational wave in 2015.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.A: foundational
options.B: supplementary
options.C: repetitive
options.D: ineffective

questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer because 'foundational' means serving as a basis upon which subsequent work is built. Weber’s experiments provided the essential groundwork for future gravitational wave research.

questions.passage: As an architect in Los Angeles in the 1950s, Helen Liu Fong became known for avoiding ______blank designs in her buildings. Instead of using standard shapes and colors, she typically explored innovative forms and daring hues.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.A: creative
options.B: bold
options.C: traditional
options.D: understandable

questions.rationale: Choice C is the best answer because 'traditional' means conventional or standard. The text contrasts Fong's innovative and daring design choices with the conventional designs that she purposely avoided.

questions.passage: It is by no means ______blank to recognize the influence of Dutch painter Hieronymus Bosch on Ali Banisadr’s paintings; indeed, Banisadr himself cites Bosch as an inspiration. However, some scholars have suggested that the ancient Mesopotamian poem Epic of Gilgamesh may have had a far greater impact on Banisadr’s work.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.A: substantial
options.B: satisfying
options.C: unimportant
options.D: appropriate

questions.rationale: Choice C is the best answer because it indicates that recognizing Bosch’s influence is not unimportant; in other words, it is significant. The text notes that while Bosch is acknowledged as an inspiration by Banisadr, some scholars argue that the Epic of Gilgamesh had a more influential impact, contrasting the two influences.

questions.passage: Scholarly discussions of gender in Shakespeare’s comedies often celebrate the rebellion of the playwright’s characters against the rigid expectations ______blank by Elizabethan society. Most of the comedies end in marriage, with characters returning to their socially dictated gender roles after previously defying them, but there are some notable exceptions.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.A: interjected
options.B: committed
options.C: illustrated
options.D: prescribed

questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer because 'prescribed' means set down as a rule or norm. Elizabethan society imposed strict gender roles that the characters rebel against, even if they ultimately conform, making 'prescribed' the fitting term.

questions.passage: Sueño de Familia is an exhibition of drawings, paintings, and ceramics that explores the artistic heritage of US-based artist Yolanda González. The exhibition ______blank five generations, featuring works by González’s great-grandfather, grandmother, mother, and niece as well as González herself.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.A: borrows
options.B: spans
options.C: judges
options.D: neglects

questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer because 'spans' means extends across. The exhibition covers works from five generations, clearly demonstrating an intergenerational connection.

questions.passage: In 2008 a complete set of ancient pessoi (glass game pieces) was uncovered from beneath a paving stone in modern-day Israel. Due to their small size, pessoi were easily misplaced, making a whole set a rare find. This has led some experts to suggest that the set may have been buried intentionally; however, without clear evidence, archaeologists are left to ______blank what happened.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.A: speculate about
options.B: dismiss
options.C: expand on
options.D: catalog

questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer because 'speculate about' means to form a theory or conjecture without definitive evidence. Since clear evidence is lacking, archaeologists can only hypothesize about the intentional burial.

questions.passage: US traffic signals didn’t always contain the familiar three lights (red, yellow, and green). Traffic lights only ______blank red and green lights until the three-light traffic signal was developed in the 1920s.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.A: avoided
options.B: featured
options.C: appreciated
options.D: disregarded

questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer because 'featured' means that the traffic signals included red and green lights as their defining characteristics before the addition of the yellow light in the 1920s.

questions.passage: Given that the conditions in binary star systems should make planetary formation nearly impossible, it’s not surprising that the existence of planets in such systems has lacked ______blank explanation. Roman Rafikov and Kedron Silsbee shed light on the subject when they used modeling to determine a complex set of factors that could support planets’ development.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.A: a discernible
options.B: a straightforward
options.C: an inconclusive
options.D: an unbiased

questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer because 'a straightforward explanation' implies a simple and direct account, which is lacking in the case of planets in binary star systems, thus necessitating more complex modeling.

questions.passage: For her 2021 art installation Anthem, Wu Tsang joined forces with singer and composer Beverly Glenn-Copeland to produce a piece that critics found truly ______blank: they praised Tsang for creatively transforming a museum rotunda into a dynamic exhibit by projecting filmed images of Glenn-Copeland onto a massive 84-foot curtain and filling the space with the sounds of his and other voices singing.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.A: restrained
options.B: inventive
options.C: inexplicable
options.D: mystifying

questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer because 'inventive' describes something that is original and creative. The installation is praised for its creative transformation of the space, making 'inventive' the ideal descriptor.

questions.passage: While most animals are incapable of passing somatic mutations—genetic alterations that arise in an organism’s nonreproductive cells—on to their offspring, elkhorn coral (Acropora palmata) presents an intriguing ______blank: in a 2022 study, researchers found that elkhorn coral produced offspring that inherited somatic mutations from a parent.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.A: hypothesis
options.B: affinity
options.C: anomaly
options.D: corroboration

questions.rationale: Choice C is the best answer because 'anomaly' means something that deviates from what is standard or expected. The fact that elkhorn coral can pass somatic mutations to its offspring is unusual compared to most animals, making it an anomaly.

questions.passage: Scientists previously thought that all electric eels belong to a single species, but a team of researchers led by zoologist C. David de Santana proved this idea wrong by ______blank that there are in fact three distinct species of electric eels.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.A: pretending
options.B: complaining
options.C: requiring
options.D: demonstrating

questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer because 'demonstrating' means showing evidence or proof. De Santana’s research provided evidence that there are three distinct species of electric eels, contradicting the previous singular species theory.

questions.passage: Studying how workload affects productivity, Maryam Kouchaki and colleagues found that people who chose to do relatively easy tasks first were less ______blank compared to those who did hard tasks first. Finishing easy tasks gave participants a sense of accomplishment, but those who tackled hard tasks first actually became more skilled and productive workers over time.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.A: secretive
options.B: efficient
options.C: outgoing
options.D: unsympathetic

questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer because 'efficient' means effective and productive. The passage contrasts the temporary satisfaction from easy tasks with the higher skill and productivity gained from doing hard tasks first, implying that those who did easy tasks first were less efficient.
